business.start.para: Mr. Speaker (Hon. Sir Littleton Groom)took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - Has the Minister for Trade and Customs yet' had time to consider the Tariff Board's reports on the iron and steel industry?
- I recently received from the Tariff Board one report on the industry referred to, and am waiting for another to complete the reports on that industry. They are receiving consideration.

-Will the Minister for Trade and Customs table at once the report of the Tariff Board on the application of the British Imperial Oil Company for assistance in connexion with the importation of case petrol?
- Yes.

- A number of people residing in and around Sydney have crystal wireless sets and make payments to the Postmaster-General's Department for the service of the broadcasting stations. Now that Farmers in Sydney has altered its wave length the owners of crystal sets are unable to get into communication with that station.Will the PostmasterGeneral Bay whether there is any means of protecting the interests of the public in such a case?
- Farmers' wave length has not been altered, and there is no reason why the owners of crystal sets should not be able to receive from it as well as from other broadcasting stations.

- Has the Treasurer received either officially or personally any serious complaints concerning Mr. Peck, the chairman of the Expropriation Board in New Guinea? If so, what action does the Minister propose to take concerning the gentleman?
- I have not received any serious complaints concerning the chairman of the Expropriation Board in New Guinea.
asked the Minister for Works and Railways, upon notice -

quote.para: Is it a fact that the Commonwealth contract forms provide that successful tenderers must grant preference to unionists?

talk.start.para: - The special conditions of contract contain the following clause: -

quote.para: In carrying out the work under this contract, preference shall be given - other things being equal - firstly, to returned soldiers and sailors with satisfactory records of service; and, secondly, to members of trade unions.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

quote.para: Whether the Government will make the completion of the North-South Railway a necessary condition before it proceeds to build railways in the Northern Territory from any other direction, or assists in the building of railways having for their object the drawing of the trade from the Northern Territory east or west?

talk.start.para: - This matter, which is one of policy, will receive consideration.
asked the Minister for Trade and Customs, upon notice -

item.para: With regard to the Minister's previous reply to questions in relation to the loss of the Dorrigo,. is it a fact that the provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act of 1854 which cover the transfer and sale of British ships refer mainly to preserving the rights, privileges and responsibilities attaching to the registry of ships under the Britishflag, and do not prohibit colonial governments exercising due precautions' for the preservation of life and property at sea within the limits of those colonies 7
If so, will he take such steps as will ensure the following data passing over from the vendor of any sea-going ship to any Australian owner ; -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Drawings, showing the vessel's stability curve.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Drawings, showing effects of all structural alterations (if any) made since the determination of the stability curve as in (a) ; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: Reasons for carrying ballast (if any), and, also, the practice with regard to the water ballast tanks when the ship is (i) in light trim; and (ii) with deck cargo?

In view of the several important points that have been raised since the Court of Marine Inquiry brought in its finding in regard to the Dorrigo disaster, will the Minister order the re-opening of the case and the- investigation - before competent naval architects - of the several matters, in order that happenings similar to the wreck of the Dorrigo may be avoided in the future?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : - 1 and 2. Thesale and transfer of British ships are subject, throughout the Empire, to the provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894, not 1854, as mentioned by the honorable member. There is no express prohibition in this act of action of the nature suggested in the question. As previously stated in my answer to the honorable member's question on the 24th ultimo it is not possible under the Merchant Shipping Act to impose in any Dominion conditions on sales and transfers made within its jurisdiction which are not equally applicable in other parts of the Empire.

item.para: Since the finding of the Court of Marine Inquiry into the loss of the Dorrigo, no new evidence whatever has. been discovered or fresh facts adduced that would warrant the reopening of the inquiry;

speech.para: LOANS FLOATED ABROAD, 1922-1926.

quote.para: What was the amount of each loan floated abroad during the years ended 30th June, 1922, 1923, 1924, 1925, and 1926 respectively ?

talk.start.para: - The particulars desired by the honorable member are as follow : -

What was the capital expenditure during the same period in the same areas?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: 1923-24. - Metropolitan areas, 56 per cent.; country areas, 44 per cent. 1924-25. - Metropolitan areas, 45 per cent. ; country areas, 55 per cent. 1925-26. - Metropolitan areas, 44 per cent. (approximately) ; country areas, 56 per cent. (approximately).

1923-24.- Metropolitan areas, £1,529,223 (56 per cent.); country areas, £1,212,018 (44 percent.). 1924-25.- £1,598,411 (47 per cent.); country areas, £1,795,796 (53 per cent.). 1925-26. - (Figures are not yet available, but willbe supplied to the honorable member at a later date).

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Have thefollowing been appointed to represent Australia at the forthcoming conference of the League of Nations at Geneva : - The Hon. J. G. Latham, M.P., Mr. Manning, M.P., Sir Arthur Rickard, and Miss Freda Bage?
Will they receive their expenses in connexion with such conference?

Will the Prime Minister furnish) the House with reasons why four members of the Nationalist party have been appointed, and no member of the Opposition, representing at the last election 1,262,992 voters?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow: - 1 and 2. Yes.

item.para: In making the appointments, the Government's only aim was to secure a delegation which would effectively represent Australia. As I have already indicated in statements to this House, the Government feels that the personnel of the delegation is such as to inspire the confidence ofthe people of Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Markets and Migration, upon notice -

item.para: How many dairy farmers are there in each State in Australia, and what is the total number of dairy farmers in Australia?
What were the average gross earnings of each dairy farmer during 1925?
What has been the total saving made by the Dairy Export Control Board in handling the exportable surplus of butter for 1925-26, and how has it been done?
How much is this saving per head of dairy farmers in Australia for the year 1925-26?

talk.start.para: - The information is being obtained.
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Whether representations have been made during recent months on behalf of cities and towns whose population exceeds 5,000 persons for a special Federal grant of £5,000,000 for road construction under similar conditions to those imposed upon shires and municipalities under the grant for country roads?
If so, what decision (if any) has been arrived at.

talk.start.para: - A deputation composed of representatives of Melbourne municipalities recently waited on the Minister for Works and Railways and urged that a grant of £3,000,000 be made for expenditure on roads within the metropolitan areas. The Minister informed the deputation that it was impossible to agree to any portion of the proposed grant under the Federal scheme being expended within the metropolitan areas. With this decision the Government concurred. A further communication has just been received from the chairman (Councillor A. J. Dunkin, Collingwood Council, Melbourne) of the conference of metropolitan municipalities on main arterial road construction, requesting a special Federal grant of £5,000,000 for the larger towns and cities of the Commonwealth. The Government is, however, unable to vary the decision already arrived at.
- On the 8th July, the honorable member for Indi (Mr. Cook) asked the following questions: -

If so, what was the quantity, and where was it imported from.

speech.para: I am now able to furnish the honorable member with the following information : -

item.para: Yes.
The imports since 1st April last were: - Canada, 53,655 centals; New Zealand, 867 centals; Chili, 49,250 centls; United States of America, 1,120 centals. Total, 104,892 centals.

What expenses, if any (a) in Australia, (b) outside Australia, has he been allowed since his appointment?
Is it a fact that, apart from salary and expenses, he receives an amount for entertainment purposes; if so, how much has he received?

speech.para: I have now received information from the Commonwealth Shipping Board to the following effect: -

item.para: Mr. Larkinhas been in London since April, 1925.
Yes.
£3,500 per annum.
Travelling allowance : (a) £102, (b) £1,356, to the 31st May, 1926.
Yes; £1,009 to the 31st May, 1926.

item.para: Area, 587 acres.
Purchased in 1913 at a cost of £12,679 17s. 7d. Cost of improvements since effected, £5,820.

Thecost of the remount depot, and including the farm, spread over a period of the past three years, averaged: - (a) Pay and allowances of personnel, £2,749; (b) maintenance of remounts, £805. 4. (a) Breaking in, training for military purposes, preparation and issue of horses for the use of the Citizen Forces; (b) area for small camps and schools of instruction; (c) site and danger area for field artillery ammunition stores; (d) growing fodder to reduce the cost of maintenance of remounts.

speech.para: I informed the honorable member that the reply I had given previously was based upon eleven months' actual figures and one month's estimated figures. I am now able to furnish the honorable member with the following complete information to 30th June last : -

item.para: Pneumatic tires, £2,045,421; tubes therefor, £321,987; total, £2,367,408.

talk.start.para: - On the 26th March, the honorable member for Melbourne (Dr. Maloney) asked me a question concerning Dr. de Luca's method of treating tuberculosis. I am now able to inform him that some preliminary information has been received, with a statement by Dr. de Luca, that when the work is complete, he will disclose full details of the laboratory process. The information at present supplied is not sufficient to enable an estimate of the value of his work to be made.

debate.para: Message from the Deputy of the Governor-General recommending an appropriation reported.
In committee( Consider ation of the message of the Deputy of the GovernorGeneral) :
Motion (by Mr. Pater son) agreed to -

quote.para: That it is expedient that an appropriation of revenue be made for the purposes of a bill for an act relating to the export of canned fruits, and for other purposes.

debate.para: Resolution reported and, by leave, adopted.
Message from the Deputy of the Governor-General recommending an appropriation reported.
Department of Home and Territories, £7,000, agreed to.

talk.start.para: . - I suggest that at this stage the Minister for Defence should take honorable members into his confidence regarding the expenditure of the departments under his control.

. - When the bill providing for an appropriation for naval purposes was before the committee, I promised to give a detailed account of the Government's naval expenditure when the estimates were under consideration. The estimates now before the committee relate only to new works; but when the naval estimates are brought forward I shall keep my promise by making a full statement on naval matters.

.- Yesterday I asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, whether any amount had been included in the estimates for carrying out the recommendation of the Public Works Committee to establish a naval training college for boys at Geelong. The Minister replied that no money had 'been placed on the estimates for that purpose. I look upon this as one of the most vital matters that has ever come before this Parliament. The Minister informed the House yesterday that from the time the training ship Tingira was taken over by the Commonwealth in 1912, at a cost of £15,000, until the present date, over 2,800 bluejackets and other naval ratings had been trained on her, and drafted to the Royal Australian Navy. During the war, the ship trained 1,000 ratings for our fleet, and in the last six months it has trained 71. The condition of the ship, as disclosed by the committee's report, is almost deplorable, and it is time we closed it up and moved to a better and more up-to-date establishment on shore, which is considered by the admiralty as the better system. But where shall we move, in view of the fact that we have to find 400 new ratings for the ships that are being built? Those new ratings have to be intensively trained in signalling, gunnery, seamanship, and other branches of naval work. Boys spend twelve months on the Tingira before they are sent on board a sea-going cruiser, or to special classes at Flinders Naval Base. Apparently that ship will continue as a training establishment during this and next year, and will then cease to function. The report presented by the Public Works Committee on the 3rd September, 1925, after an exhaustive consideration of the matter, stated -

quote.para: George's Head does not lend itself to the construction of the buildings such as are proposed. With regard to Flinders Naval Base, it was reported that the creation of a boys' naval training establishment there would entail just as much cost for buildings as would Geelong, and in addition a considerable amount for clearing. Moreover, it offered the vital objection of mixing the boys and grown men.

speech.para: With that view I entirely agree. Paragraph 22 of the committee's report, which is their recommendation, reads -

quote.para: With this reservation as to title, the committee is satisfied from its investigation that an establishment of the class contemplated is necessary, and that Geelong offers an ideal site for its location; and recommends that when the land becomes Commonwealth property, necessary construction work be put in hand as early as possible.

speech.para: As no amount is placed on the Estimates for carrying out the committee's recommendations, the question asked the other day by the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) arises, " Where are we in this matter?" There is an annual wastage of 200 in the personnel of our fleet. Where can boys be trained in that number? It is highly undesirable to mix boys and men at Flinders Naval Base. The Public Works Committee decided in favour of an establishment at Geelong. The Tingira has been gathering in annually about 300 boys at a plastic age, and has been a God-send to thousands of lads who wished to go into the navy. If a lad wishes to go into the navy, he may go either via the Jervis Bay Naval College or by the Tingira entry. In the former casey he sits 'for., examination at the age of thirteen, and, if he is successful, .passes into the. college at the age of fourteen. The demo,cratic system . of ' allowing two cadetships yearly from the- Tingira . to the Jervis Bay College should appeal to honorable members . opposite. . If the Tingira is closed, and, as has been suggested, enlistments, are sent to. Flinders Naval Base by direct entry at the age of seventeen," there will be no more cadetships from the lower deck of the Tingira, to Jervis "Bay College.. I know that the Minister for Defence has always favoured a greater age than fourteen years for naval recruiting. That is borne out by conversations .with the Minister, and also by a paragraph - T do not know whether it is true-which appeared in the Daily Guardian about a fortnight ago, in which the Minister is reported to have said - .
I have definitely decided to make an end of Tingira's method of naval- recruiting. I propose to stop the recruiting of boys agted 14-i years. I will take boys' of at least 16 years.

In this matter I am vitally opposed to the Minister. I wish that I had time to quote some of the views respecting the recruiting age as expressed by men who are now dead, but who served for" a lifetime in the British Navy, and in some cases rose to be Admirals of the Fleet; but the views of Nelson, Rodney, Jellicoe, and Beatty are well known, and agree with those expressed in a statement by an Admiral of the Fleet, the late Lord Fisher, who had 61 years' service in the Navy, ' and was responsible for the efficiency of the British. Fleet at ' the' time-, of the Jutland naval .engagement. By' scrapping hundreds of obsolete ships,which, could neither chase . nor steam away, and replacing them by modern vessels,' he brought the fleet to a high standard of efficiency. In his lectures to his officers in the Mediterranean he said -

quote.para: The enemy will suddenly confront us as an apparition-. At every moment we must be' ready. Can this be acquired by grown men? No, it is the force of habit. You must commence early. Our Nelsons and Benbows began the sea life when they first put their, breeches on. The brother of the Black Prince (John 0'Gaunt) joined the navy, and was ina sea fight when he was 10 years .of age. Far exceeding anything known in history does out future Trafalgar depend on promptitude and rapid decision, and on every eventuality having been foreseen by. those in command. . But these attributes cannot toe, acquired late in life. So begin early arid' work continuously.

speech.para: Everything hinges on the question of age. If the Tingira is scrapped, and the boys have to go to Flinders Base, it will be too late to train them properly at seventeen years of " age. Every" naval; authority agrees about that. Admiral Lord Fisher, commenting on an incident at Trafalgar, when a midshipman nine years of age, during a heavy gale, endeavoured to catch a blue-jacket who had slipped off one of the upper yards, said -

quote.para: I consider this instance a striking testimony to the inestimable benefit of . sending little boys to - sea when they are young. What splendid Nelsonic qualities were developed! That is the midshipman of the older day, and one often has misgivings that the modern system of sending boys to sea much older is a bad one when such magnificent results were produced .by the old methods. One would like to give it a trial of sending boys to sea at nine years old: The Osborne system of naval education has its great merits, but it has been a grievous blow to it departing from the original conception of entering at twelve years of age.

speech.para: Now let us come -nearer home. The second naval member, of the Naval . Board, Captain Cayley, a most efficient officer, when giving evidence before the' Public Works Committee, on pages 2.' and 3, said -

quote.para: My experience in the Royal Navy and in the Royal Australian Navy is' that the Australian boy is quite as good as boys of corresponding agc and training in the Royal Navy, and, intellectually, he is more alert; also, he does take to the sea if he is caught young. Whenthe Royal Australian Navy was started in 1913 it was necessary to' recruit grown men, and, as a body, they were not a success.....
The establishment at Osborne House will iri no way duplicate .any service that is being rendered by - either Jervis Bay Naval College or

Flinders Naval Base..... The average number of entrants now is about six per week; but, unless we can expand the training establishment, we shall have to close down on recruiting - which would be a tragedy* - and borrow more, ratings from the Royal Navy. At present about 90 per cent, of the personnel of the squadron is Australian,' and our aim is to gradually eliminate the 10 per cent, of ratings borrowed from the Royal Navy.

speech.para: Commander Garsia, Officer Commanding. the Tingira, when before the Public Works Committee, on' pages 11 and 12, stated! -

quote.para: Under the stress of action, when men ' have to be alert, physically fit, and. 'trained to the last minute, and when they must be imbued with the necessary esprit de corps and have enthusiasm for their job, the .need for a long period of service becomes manifest. The. spiritual, as well as the material, side is essential in a fighting service like the Navy. We cannot do without the right' spirit.' Material knowledge,' though important, is less essential.

speech.para: I do not know whether the Minister for Defence fully realizes' the high educa-tiona! standard that is necessary to enable petty officers to attain commissioned rank. Now that the Tingira is to be scrapped, I suppose that enlistments, say, . seventon years of age, will have three months' training at Flinders Naval Base, a quarter of which will be given to education, and after that they will go to sea. I ask, is it possible for a man to study mathematics, algebra, trigonometry, and physics on board a vessel at sea, and to qualify for commissioned rank? From considerable experience, I know that only in exceptional cases will that, be possible. Thus, in two or three years there will be no petty officers qualified to take commissioned rank. The Minister or the Naval Board may decide to extend the time for educational training at Flinders Naval Base; . but then the Minister will have .difficulties to face when he goes to the Treasurer for money. If there is a wastage of. 200 or 300 each year in the personnel of the fleet, the men have to be trained somewhere. Geelong and the Tingira have been rejected for training purposes, and the men will have to be trained at Flinders. More accommodation will be required there, and the Minister will -have to go, cap in hand, to the Treasurer asking for money to facilitate the erection of accommodation for the training of hundreds of men. He will say to the Treasurer, " We are going to extend tha time for educational training, because it cannot be carried out efficiently at sea, and I want accommodation for the men ;at Flinders."

talk.start.para: - The Public Works Committee opposed the training of boys at Flinders.

- Because it. approved of Geelong. Money must be spent at Flinders if the Geelong" scheme . is rejected ; but why not .spend it at Geelong, in accordance with the recommendation of a committee representative- pf !;:all - "sides of Parliament. I suppose 'on board ship no men- are-, more important than. the gunners and gunners'- mates, -and; the torpedo gunners' mates.- -It- is 'they who will handle' the magnicent weapons of the ' new cruisers^ sub marine's, and aeroplane carrier. -Unless we have properly trained men for these responsible' positions, in a few years'., time, if we enter another war, we shall be right, up against it. On the subject . pf efficiency, I could' quote hundreds of our leading naval men. On. the. 17th " December, , 1893, King Edward VII., who knew as much about the Navy. as any of his admirals, wrote to Sir .Henry Ackland, who was at that time, I. believe, in the Ministry, and urged that every possible step should be tak.en to- maintain . the efficiency of the .Navy. The situation, in Britain at that time was similar to that which we are facing " to-day. ' The Minister for Defence is, to., a certain extent, being politically bludgeoned by the Treasurer. .1 understand the. situation perfectly. I have no doubt that he requested the. Treasurer to provide. sufficient money on , 'the Estimates to enable the Geelong scheme to be carried- out, and pointed out .that at the last Imperial Conference, the Prime Minister- (Mr. Bruce), after consulting with Admiral; Sir Alan Everett and Lieutenant-Commander' Bush, who. accompanied him to London, promised that Australia would . undertake a certain- developmental programme" for defence purposes, which .involved, the construction of new cruisers, submarines," 'and a -seaplane carrier. The, two experts.' were doubtless asked to estimate the cost' o'f this extra equipment, and did so,' but, . xmf fortunately, they had insufficient data on which to frame a reliable estimate, "and this has now been largely exceeded. . Con-sequently the Minister for Defence is in a* difficult position. The Treasurer has probably said that he is willing to' provide an . amount equivalent to the estimate that the experts made, but 'nothing further. Of what use will it "be for us to spend £7,000,000 on new cruisers if we do not intend to man' them efficiently when we get them? It is a well recognized naval principle that boys must be secured young for naval training: - lit' would -not be satisfactory to man' vessels of the cruiser type with -men who had not begun their training until they were seventeen years of age, and lacked the sea instinct. The Public Works Committee recommended an expenditure of £88,700 at Geelong in " the first stage " to enable training to be commenced; £24,300 in the second stage " after occupation," which showed clearly that the expenditure in the first stage was sufficient to begin operations there; and £22,535 in what was called the " future." Surely we should not hesitate to spend even the whole of this amount of £136,535 to ensure proper training for those who will be required to man the cruisers. I point out to honorable members that it is highly desirable that these men should be in continuous training. If there is a break in the training, difficulties will undoubtedly arise within two or three years' time. I am informed on high authority that if even £20,000 could be spent at Geelong this year to provide such essential services as water and sewerage, training could be commenced. I have no doubt that we shall be told that the Minister is acting on the advice of his experts; but can we expect naval officers to stand up against the Treasurer and the Minister for Defence in a matter of this kind? When the Minister says "No money," the Naval Board are forced to agree; so the responsibility rests with the Treasurer. I wish to make it quite clear that I am not speaking on this matter at the request of the Minister for Defence; but I am well aware of his difficulty. I am also well acquainted with the views of all our leading naval authorities on this question, and they believe that we should follow the example of the Admiralty, which, while effecting great economies, is nevertheless carrying on the work of training boys for naval service. I give a warning to the Government as to the position to which it is drifting. I urge the Treasurer with all the sincerity I possess to provide at least £20,000 for expenditure at Geelong this year, so that the scheme may be established. Unless provision to that extent at least is made, a deadly blow will be struck at the efficiency of the Royal Australian Navy. Trouble will be caused two or three years hence in regard to the efficient manning of the Fleet, and dire trouble should we be engaged in hostilities.

.- At last we have been given some information as to the intention of the Government with regard to future naval training, and as the representative of the Corio Division, in which Geelong is situated, I must confess that I am surprised at the statement that has been made. We mustregard naval training as being quite different from military training. In the light of the statement that has been made, I feel constrained to ask what has become of the proud boast made at the time the Royal Australian Navy was established ? Surely, if it were considered necessary in those piping days of peace to set up our navy as a unit separate from the British Navy, it is necessary today that we should maintain it. I freely admit that opinions may change with the passage of the years, but in my view it is far more necessary now than it ever was before that Australia should have her own navy. I should like to see our navy staffed with Australian-born men if possible, or at least with men who have been imbibing the spirit of the Australian nation from their earliest years.
- All the Tingira boys are imbued with the Australian spirit.

- Yes; all who have gone through that school are. But the training required for the Navy is different from that needed by the Army. It has been said frequently that the Australia a can adapt himself to any circumstances, and that is probably why our soldiers gave such an excellent account of them-' selves as they did overseas. The remarks of the honorable member for Wentworth should carry considerable weight on account of his naval experience. I believe that the only way to get men of the right type is to catch boys when they are young. The Public Works Committee strongly recommended that the naval training establishment should be located at Osborne House, Geelong. I need not enter into a dissertation upon the benefit of placing the establishment there, where there are fine buildings and a large bluestone residence, capable of providing accommodation for hundreds of men. 1 do not even consider it necessary to attempt to justify the expenditure of £20,000 that the honorable member for Wentworth suggested would he required to establish the training school there. If tlie work were to be done precisely iti accordance with the wishes of the department, no doubt £80,000 would have to be expended, but I think that it could be carried out at considerably less cost. The Treasurer should consider the matter from the point of view of the safety of the nation. If that were done, provision would be made for the immediate needs.

speech.para: Another item to which I desire to refer is the sum of £8,000 for new buildings for the naval air service. This amount is altogether inadequate for present requirements. Prominence has been given in the press to the recent inquiry into the circumstances of the fatal accident that occurred a few days ago to two airmen from the Point Cook flying school. It was stated in the evidence that little or no accommodation was provided for married men employed there, and the fact was elicited that one of the victims had to travel 60 miles daily to and from his home. If proper accommodation for married men is not available in the vicinity of their employment, the Government should take early steps to provide it.

I hope that the Minister for Defence will be able to influence the Treasurer in the direction indicated by the honorable member for Wentworth, and that the sum necessary to provide for the immediate transfer of the men from the Tingira to Osborne House will be voted.

talk.start.para: . - I should like the Minister to furnish the committee with further information on this matter before a vote is taken. Why should the Tingira be removed from Sydney at all ?
- Because she is in a rotten condition.

- But she could easily be replaced by another vessel. It will prove very expensive to train the boys ou land instead of on board ship, and some good reason should be given for the proposal. The honorable member for Wentworth mentioned the number of men who had been trained on the Tingira, and had risen to high positions. Those who are. now to be trained on shore will not have similar opportunities to become officers.
- I claim that twelve months' training on the Tingira is preferable to three months at Flinders base
- I understand that it is proposed to train the men for three months on shore, and then put them on a ship. I hope that the Minister will explain the position.

speech.para: The municipality of Randwick is anxious about the decision that the Government has come to regarding the Randwick rifle range. Recently the range was handed over to the- State Government, but, much to the annoyance of the local council, the Commonwealth authorities have reserved a strip of land running through it. The council claims that this will spoil the proposed subdivision, and that plenty of land is available at the Long Bay range. It is claimed that the whole of the range at Randwick should be transferred to the State. At the Long Bay range riflemen walk nearly a quarter of a mile before they reach the first firing point, and it is thought that this land, which at present is lying idle, should be made available for building purposes. The Government should sell the land to those who desire to live at the seaside. The Randwick .council and the various progress societies interested claim that the military, authorities should not monopolise land for which they have no use. I shall reserve what I have to say about the Navy until I have heard the Minister's reply to the honorable member for Wentworth.

talk.start.para: . - I find in the Estimates two references to the equipment which was presented to the Commonwealth by the British Government, the estimated value of which, speaking from memory, was at the time £2,000,000. A considerable time ago, I referred to the fact that a good deal of expense was being incurred to prevent depreciation in leather and other equipment comprised in the gift. A very considerable portion of the gift equipment is, no doubt, now out of date. Honorable members are aware, that the Commonwealth has incurred large expenditure in reconditioning gift aeroplanes which had been allowed lo lie and rot for some time before any attempt was made to use them. I should like to know from the Minister what is the present " position with regard to this gift equipment received from the British Government. If, as has been stated, a considerable portion of it is now obso- lete, can serve no useful . purpose, and is in fact a source of expense for maintenance, we might as well sell it. I should . like to know whether there are any difficulties in the way . of disposing of' it.

.- The honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Marks) has raised a question concerning training for the Navy. It is known to honorable members generally that the honorable member . has had a great deal of experience in connexion with the Navy, and any opinion he expresses on the matter is worthy of consideration. He is perfectly well aware that the matter to which he has referred has received the greatest consideration from the Minister for Defence and his advisers, and reference to the estimates and to the naval construction policy of the Government will show that we are passing through an extraordinary period in the history of our nation. During a little over three years, the Government is proposing an expenditure of nearly £7,250,000 to give effect to its naval construction policy. It is also providing for something even more important, and that is the necessary personnel... Honorable members have referred to the human factor, and the psychology necessary for the training of lads for the Navy, and they will recognize that the human factor is of even greater importance than is the construction ' policy. Those who recall the work of our Navy during the late war will recognize that at the outset we owed the safety of our homes to the fact that we were so . extremely fortunate as to have the Australia in our home waters. Had it not been for this, our ports would have been exposed to shell fire, and our people to the grievous injuries which would possibly have resulted therefrom. The honorable member for Wentworth holds very definite views on the subject of the training of boys for the Navy. But it has been possible to provide means for necessary naval construction only by the adoption for the time being of an altered system of training. I do not think that the honorable member fully appreciates the difference in mentality between the Australian and English youth. Whilst it may be necessary in Great Britain to catch boys very young, from- fourteen to fifteen years of age for training for the Navy, I do not think . that the same necessity exists in this country. Our youth aTe better developed, far better educated, and are drawn from a higher social class, living under better economic conditions than, speaking generally, the boys who are trained for service in the navy in the Old Country. The whole matter is under serious consideration, but I propose taking boys for training at a later age, and although they will be sent to Flinders they will not be allowed to associate either at mess or during training with the older men -there. I believe that the course I propose will meet the situation.- From the reports presented to me by my advisers, I have no hesitation in saying that. when between 1928 and 1929 our two modern cruisers, our modern sea-going submarines, and seaplane-carrier are completed the necessary personnel will be available to fully man these vessels. What is more important, from my point of view, is that .over 90 per cent, of it will be Australian-born.- We want something more than an Australian Navy in name. It must be composed of Australians, and will be entirely Australian when we are able to fill the higher ranks with boys who have gone through the Jervis Bay Naval College. Boys who have passed through that college and proceeded to England on the completion of their studies there have proved themselves most efficient, and in their subsequent training in England have not only held their own, but in many cases have surpassed lads trained in England. I do not wish to boast about our country, but I say that at no time has there been such progress made in connexion with its defence as there has been during the last two years. Whatever view we may hold concerning defence, we are all agreed as to the need for it until something is established to take its place. I hope that that will eventually be found in the development of the League of Nations; by the representation upon it of all countries in the world, and the exercise of its moral influence to prevent war in the distant future. We have not yet reached that day, and, in the meantime, it is our duty to be prepared to defend as effectively as possible this outpost of the Empire. The honorable member for Corio (Mr. Lister) and the honorable member for Wentworth have referred to the Public Works Committee, a body for which we all have the greatest respect, and whose work has been of great value to the Parliament. Whilst respecting the opinion of that committee as much as any other member of the committee, I have a duty to perform irrespective of its recommendation. I have to consider all that is connected with defence, and to urge the Treasurer (Dr. Earle Page) to find the means to give effect to what I believe to be the policy most vital to retain an effective defence. But there is no member of the committee who does not clearly recognize that it is not possible for us to defend this country against the attack of an enemy in the Pacific. We might hold off such an attack and protect Australia from invasion until the British Navy could come to our assistance. This country with a population of only 6,000,000 could not afford the expenditure necessary for its complete protection. I estimate that an expenditure of not less than £50,000,000 a year would be necessary for the next ten years to provide a defence to wholly protect Australia against any attacks from other countries bordering on the Pacific. Fortunately, there appears to be no likelihood of war in the Pacific. We are living on most amicable terms with our neighbours, but we must be in a position to defend ourselves if called upon to do so. I regret very much the necessity of curtailing any portion of the navy establishment, but some curtailment has been necessary, and I assure honorable members that the matter of naval training has been given very grave consideration. My own view is that it will be possible at the end of 1928-29 to re-introduce the system of boy training if it should then be found advisable or necessary. Tn view of the liberal way in which the Treasurer has met my demands for expenditure, I am not disposed to force upon him expenditure that is not absolutely necessary.

speech.para: In answer to the honorable member for South Sydney (Mr. E. Riley), I may be allowed to say that the department has adopted a very sympathetic attitude concerning rifle ranges and the interests of rifle associations. I shall look into the matter of the rifle range at Randwick. The Government has been asked by the State Governments to give up certain lands in its possession. Last year, after a great deal of pressure, it agreed to the transfer of {he whole of the frontage to Oxford-street, Paddington, to the New South Wales Govern^ ment.

talk.start.para: - Nothing has been done to remove the buildings upon that property.

- I have already informed the honorable member for South Sydney that it is not the Federal Government, but the State Government, that is holding up the work there. I have great hesitation in agreeing to give up land which, although it may not be required by the Defence Department to-day, possibly will be required for defence purposes within the next 100 years.
- What position will the honorable gentleman occupy then?
- He will be in the air force then!

- The policy I have adopted is to refuse to alienate federal property in the possession of the Defence Department. I have been prepared, as I did in connexion with a property in Western Australia, to lease it to the State Government for 99 years at a rental of ls. a year. If possible, I shall apply that principle at Randwick. It is always difficult, however, to dispossess people once they have established even a partial claim to an area of land. One body to whom I gave a 99-years' lease sent me a very plausible letter, saying that the land had been converted into recreation grounds, and that my approval was taken for. gr anted, because, as Minister, for Health, 1 would appreciate that the need for recreation was more urgent than the need for defence. Of course, public health and defence are interdependent, because, unless the community is healthy, it can neither develop nor defend its possessions. Honorable members, must agree that the estimates represent a considerable advance upon the provision made in previous years. They will observe also that almost the whole of the money is to be spent in Australia. My object is to strengthen the navy by fully equipping and efficiently maintaining the fleet which Parliament has authorized, so that, should the necesity for defending Australia arise, it may Worthily uphold the Anzac tradition.
- Has the Minister anything to say about the accommodation at Point Cook?

- Having regard to the fact that the coroner's inquest on the recent fatality is proceeding, and that the whole matter is sab judice, it would be better to allow it to remain in abeyance until I am able to make a complete statement upon the defence estimates.

.- The amount provided in the Estimates for the civil aviation branch is £2,680, as compared with £4,200 last year. All honorable members, particularly the Minister for Defence, will agree that the proposed vote is a very small sum for such an important service. We all are agreed that Australia should be able to defend itself should the necessity arise; but, fortunately, as has been observed by several honorable members, so far as one can see ahead, this continent is in less danger of foreign aggression now than at any previous time in its history. The war risk, apparently, belongs to the remote future, but the bread-and-butter needs of the people are of immediate concern. Therefore, I again draw the attention of the Minister, who, I know, is sympathetic, to the need for providing a larger sum for the development of civil aviation. I have on many previous occasions urged the Government to agree to the extension of the aerial mail service from Derby to Wyndham. At present the Western Australian airways extend from Fremantle to Derby, a distance of 1,600 miles, and it is desired that the service should cover a further distance of 472 miles to Wyndham. At one time the annual cost of a weekly service from Derby to Wyndham was estimated :it £9,000 per annum, but, by the use of a smaller and more efficient type of aeroplane, that figure could be considerably reduced. Landing grounds were estimated to cost £3,200. Even those sums are small in comparison with the expenditure that has been incurred in the more thickly-populated parts of the continent. With the exception of Darwin, Wyndham is the most isolated settlement in Australia. It has a mail service every six weeks for eight months in the year, and for the remainder of the year a very irregular service, if any. Naturally, the Defence Department judges all civil aviation proposals in relation to their influence upon the defence of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth Government regards the development of the remote portions of the continent as mainly the concern of the States; but I submit that a sparsely-settled area like the Kimberleys constitutes a menace to the whole of Australia. This Parliament has acknowledged that fact by paying large bounties to the Queensland sugar industry in order to encourage the settlement of white population in the north of that State. Such a development is highly desirable in the interests of the nation, but the present policy is responsible for ill-balanced development. North of the Tropic of Capricorn there are 6,000 white people on the western side of the continent, as compared with 180,000 on the eastern side. If the danger from the north, which the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Marks) thinks he foresees, should prove real, the weak spot in our ramparts will be the north-west of Western Australia. If landing grounds were established and a regular civil aviation service were conducted . along the coast, our aviators would acquire training and local knowledge which would be of immense advantage in the event of Australia being embroiled with another nation. So far as the Commonwealth's interest in k is concerned, the north-west might as well be part of the Chinese empire. To-day Malay poachers from the Dutch islands are gathering trepang off the north-west coast, and are treating it by boiling plants ashore. They carry on their operations month in and month out, but never within 100 miles of the ordinary tracks of steamers. The only wealth that is being won from the Kimberley coast is being taken by aliens without let or hindrance by what is supposed to be a sovereign Commonwealth. Some time ago, a young pearler saw a Malay lugger at work off the north-west coast. He boarded the vessel and compelled the Malay skipper to sign the log with an admission that he was engaged in taking trepang from Australian waters. I brought the facts under the notice of the then Minister for Trade and Customs, and, for all the interest he showed in the matter, this theft of marine wealth might as well have been occurring in Madagascar. The north-west coast is absolutely neglected by Commonwealth departments. What happens up there is not any Federal. Minister's " pigeon." I am sure that the Minister for Health will recognize that an aerial mail and passenger service is of the utmost importance to the health as well as to the defence of the north-west. The pathetic death of Lady Campbell illustrates the conditions there. This lady resided, with her husband and three children, at Waterloo station. She was preparing to leave for Wyndham - 164 miles distant - for her confinement when she suddenly became ill. A messenger was sent to Wyndham for a doctor, who set out at once on horseback, but arrived too late to save the life of the unfortunate woman. From the time the messenger left the station until the doctor arrived at the station eleven days elapsed. If the aeroplane service for which I am now pleading had been in operation two lives would have been saved. Surely the narration of this tragedy should be sufficient to convince the committee of the stern necessity for an aviation service in that distant part of the continent. Australia cannot afford to sacrifice the lives of people who are engaged in opening up the out-back areas. I confidently ask for the Minister's favorable consideration of the urgent request of the residents in the extreme north-west of the continent.

.- On several previous occasions I have brought under the notice of the Minister for Defence the need for the erection of an aerodrome at Rockhampton. It has been estimated that the 74 acres required for the aerodrome would cost about £3,170, plus the cost of preparing the area- £330- ^ making a total of £3,500. The Minister, in commenting upon that estimate, said, " As such a considerable expenditure is involved, I regret that the funds available for civil aviation services will not permit of any further action at present." An aerodrome at Rockhampton would be a tremendous aid to the development of civil aviation in Queensland. That city, which has a population of 26,000, is the chief city of- central Queensland, and is the port of a very rich pastoral, agricultural, and mining area. The residents of the back-country about

speech.para: Longreach, Clermont, Springsure, Rolleston, Barcaldine, Blackall, Winton, and Nebo would be served by the establishment of an aerodrome at Rockhampton, for they would be able to reach the city of Rockhampton by aeroplane. In the absence of an aerodrome at Rockhampton, it is impossible to develop civil aviation there. The only landing ground for an aeroplane is the race-course, on which there are so many obstacles that an aviator places his life in jeopardy if he attempts to land there, although some have successfully done so. The people of Rockhampton want an aerodrome where any aeroplane may land safely. The cost of £3,500 should not daunt the Minister, because it is a mere bagatelle by comparison with expenditure incurred by the Government to provide much less-needed facilities. When proposals for the construction of new railways are being considered, the question whether they will pay is not the only one to be studied. Railways are often built merely to open up new country. If the residents of the western part of Queensland, who, at the present time, are suffering from the effects of a drought, are to enjoy some of the amenities of life such as are enjoyed in the large centres of civilization, the Government must spend this sum of £3,500 to provide the proposed aerodrome. That would make it possible for the people of the western parts to travel to Rockhampton by aeroplane. A number of aeroplanes are operating in the back country of Queensland, and are becoming increasingly popular. I am pleased to say that up to date there has not been a serious accident with them. The Civil Aviation Department has been starved for funds. The expenditure in that department last year was approximately £131,000 - a truly niggardly amount for a great public department. I give the Minister for Defence credit for taking a live interest in .civil aviation ; he has been to the backblocks. and is aware of the disabilities of the settlers there. I hope that he will give to this . proposal the measure- of sympathetic consideration that its importance warrants, and will approve of it. I have not mentioned this matter during the last few months, because I have been waiting until the Estimates were brought forward.

talk.start.para: .-In reply to the honorable member for Kalgoorlie, I assure him that, although money for civil aviation is not included in the Works and Buildings Estimates, the appropriation of£250,000 agreed to by the Parliament a few weeks ago is available for the Minister to use if he considers that it would be justifiable to use it, or any portion of it, for civil instead of defence aviation. The matter of civil aviation is under discussion by the cabinet, and I shall outline the Government's policy, and give the committee all the information it desires, on matters connected with defence, when the Estimate's are under consideration. .

speech.para: Proposed vote agreed to.
Department of Trade and Customs.
Proposed vote- £10,380.

talk.start.para: .- The potato-growers of Australia have during recent years suffered from a succession of unprofitable seasons. The year before last . they had too good a crop, and potatoes were so abundant that in many places it was not profitable to dig and market them. Last year they had a fairly good season, and this year the average yield is about 2 tons to the acre, which will not compensate them for previous bad years. They receive little or no benefit from the protection policy of this country, although they are nearly all good protectionists. They grow a commodity for the sale of which they depend on' the home market. No potatoes are exported from this country, and the growers have unselfishly supported duties imposed with the object of establishing new industries. For many years they have contributed their quota to the establishment of other industries. During some seasons they may do well, but over the period of the last 30 years their business has not been a flourishing one. With a yield of only 2 tons to the acre, following upon bad seasons, the market is now being deluged with importations from New Zealand. There are two grounds of objection to those importations. First, there is the danger of potato disease being introduced. I have read that 25 tons of New Zealand potatoes have been condemned in Melbourne, and some time ago I asked the

speech.para: Minister whether any New Zealand potatoes hadbeen condemned in Sydney.. Iunderstand that inquiries are still in progress with a view to supplying me with an answer to that question. The danger of the introduction of the powdery scab disease cannot be overstated. Now that mining has almost ceased there, the city of Ballarat depends largely upon the primary producers' in the surrounding country, of whom there is no more important section than the potato-growers. If the disease obtained a hold in the potato-growing districts near Ballarat, business people would be almost ruined, apart from the ruin of the potato-growers themselves. It is, a remarkable fact that the only shipment of NewZealand potatoes to Melbourne was condemned, and that Melbourne is the only port in Australia where New Zealand potatoes have been condemned. It is safe to assume from those facts that there is laxity in examining the imports elsewhere. I ask the Minister not to be content with the examination made in New South Wales. It is an anomaly that, although the Commonwealth Government inspects everything else coming into the country, the inspection of potatoes is delegated to State officials. I do not wish to impute motives to any one; I merely state that the only shipment to Melbourne has been condemned, while many shipments to New South Wales have been accepted. I hope that the Minister will insist upon a rigid examination being made. Apart from the effect of the importations upon the price of potatoes, the existence of the potatogrowing industry is threatened by the introduction of this disease.

I turn from the introduction of diseased potatoes to mention the duty on potatoes. It is only once in several years that there is a shortage of supplies, and immediately that condition arises, there is no competition from abroad. The potato-growers have already asked for a duty of £4 a ton, and I hope that the Minister will expedite the hearing of their application by the Tariff Board. Evidence will be submitted showing the precarious position of many potato-growers. I hope that the Minister will instruct the board to attend to this matter atonce, and make an early recommendation to Parliament.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to direct attention to the recent action of the Minister by which the price of sugar in Western Australia was increased. I have arrived from Perth to-day, and I take this, the earliest opportunity I could get, of bringing the matter forward. Widespread indignation has been caused throughout Western Australia' by the increase in the retail price of sugar. The events leading up to the action by the Minister are important. Until the year 1922, when the sugar agreement was made, manufacturers and others in Western Australia bought sugar f.o.b. Adelaide, and were under a great disadvantage as to price. Under the agreement of 1922 provision was made for a flat rate in all the States. That agreement imposed upon Perth a disability that did not apply to the other capital cities. The flat rate in the other States applied to the capital cities, but in Western Australia it applied toFremantle only. The consequence was that the manufacturers and the consuming public in the Perth district were placed under a grave disability.

- I would remind the honorable member that the committee in dealing with the estimates of expenditure for additions, new works, buildings, &c. If he is allowed to discuss the price of sugar, the committee may be drawn into a debate on the general Estimates.
- Is there any difference between discussing the price of sugar and discussing a disease in potatoes?

speech.para: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.Had the honorable member for Ballarat (Mr. McGrath) not concluded his remarks when he did, I should have called him to order.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to inform the honorable member for Ballarat (Mr. McGrath) that I shall do my best to expedite the hearing of the application before the Tariff Board for an increase in the duty on potatoes. I wish to repudiate entirely the suggestion that the Minister is responsible for anything that has happened in Western Australia.
- I rise to a point of order. I have been precluded from stating my case, and Iwish to know whether the Minister is in order in attempting to reply.

speech.para: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.The Minister is out of order in replying to the remarks of the honorable member for Perth (Mr. Mann).

talk.start.para: - The position in Western Australia respecting the price of sugar has arisen entirely because of the greed of the retail grocers there.

speech.para: Proposed vote agreed to.
Departmentof Health.
Proposed vote, £41,385, agreed to.
Departmentof Markets and Migration.
Proposed vote, £3,000, agreed to.
Territories of the Commonwealth.
Proposed vote, £66,500.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to refer to the item, " Construction and filling of petrol tank," in relation to the Northern Territory. I have frequently said that every effort should be made to cheapen the cost of production in the north and north-west of Australia, and this can be brought about in the early stages at least by the Government facilitating and cheapening the supply of petrol and crude oil at the various ports of the north. I know that tanks have been erected at Darwin, but whether for petrol or crude oil, to. meet the requirements of the public, I do not know. It is time that we had that information. The other day I saw some small 450-gallon tanks at the works of the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited; and, if the people of the far north could obtain their petrol supplies in tanks of that capacity, it would be of tremendous assistance in helping the development of the country. Petrol is required for the motor car, the motor tractor, and, in many instances, for pumping plants. I should like to know what the Government intends to do to enable the people of the Northern Territory to obtain petrol and crude oil as cheaply as possible.

. - I endorse the remarks of the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory). The supply of petrol and crude oil will play an important part in the development of the Northern Territory. The rail freight on fuel oil to Oodnadatta is £19 9s. 5d. a ton,but the total cost of delivery at Alice Springs is £37 19s. 5d. a ton. This cost is prohibitive. Recently I had the pleasure of riding on a motor truck carrying 21/2 tons of merchandise and mails over indescribable tracks in the Northern Territory, and the speed at which it travelled was a revelation to me. In two days we travelled 300 miles. If the Government established facilities for the bulk handling of oil, say, at Port Augusta and at the railhead, much of the cost of bringing supplies from Melbourne would be eliminated. Recently the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited notified one of the largest consumers of petrol in the Territory that he must not increase his sales of Commonwealth Oil Refineries spirit. In effect, he was told that he had reached the maximum of his supplies. I am satisfied that the cost of petrol in the far north could be considerably reduced by establishing bulk depots at railheads and northern ports.

.- On the 18th December, 1924, Cabinet approved of the establishment at Port Darwin of one 8,000-gallon crude-oil tank and one 450-gallon petrol tank, including pipe lines, distributing depots, excavations, foundations, &c. These are provided for the navy.Until two or three large tanks are established there, it will not be possible for the Government to consider providing petrol for private use. I realize the difficulties referred to by the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) and the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson). When I was in Central Australia, it was costing £17 a ton to take petrol from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs, and that was absolutely prohibitive. I have been in consultation with the Chief Commissioner of Commonwealth Railways on the matter, and inquiries have been made as to whether it would be possible to distribute petrol in small lots from Darwin southwards, but so far nothing definite has been done. It will be necessary, I think, to wait until the petrol tanks that are being constructed there are completed.

speech.para: This work is under the control of the Department of Works and Railways. It is estimated that the expenditure on it during the year 1926-27 will be £3,000, and that amount is being set aside for the purpose. The vote last year was £17,300. In view of the representations that have been made, I will bring the matter before the Government again to see whether, when the tanks are completed, it will be possible to supply petrol in small lots to graziers and others in the Northern Territory who need it. The investigation made up to date show that it would be expensive to operate a scheme of the kind ; but we may be able to find a way out of the difficulty.
Proposed vote agreed to.
Motion (by Sir Neville Howse) agreed to -

quote.para: That there be granted to His Majesty to the services of the year 1926-27, for the purposes of additions, new works, buildings, &c, a sum not exceeding £296,734.

speech.para: Resolution reported.
Standing Orders suspended; resolution adopted.
Resolution of Ways and Means, based on resolution of Supply, reported and adopted.

quote.para: That Dr. Earle Page and Sir Neville Howse do prepare and bring in a bill to carry out the foregoing resolution.

speech.para: Bill presented by Dr. Earle Page and passed through all its stages without amendment or debate.

debate.para: In committee(Consideration of message from the Deputy of the GovernorGeneral) :
Motion (by Dr. Earle Page) agreed to-

quote.para: That it is expedient that an appropriation of moneys be made for the purposes of a bill for an act to authorize the raising and expending of certain sums of money.

debate.para: Standing Orders suspended, and resolution adopted.

quote.para: That Dr. Earle Page and Mr. Hill do prepare and bring in a bill to carry out the foregoing resolution.

debate.para: Bill presented by Dr. Earle Page, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill covers the loan programme for the year 1926-27, as recently submitted with the budget. The total of the loan estimates for Commonwealth works, &c, is £10,560,499. For the redemption of the Port Augusta to Oodnadatta railway loans, it is necessary to raise £90,340. It is proposed also that the Treasurer shall raise moneys required by the Federal Capital Commission. The amount to be provided this year is £2,000,000. The total of these items is £12,650,839. From this there may be deducted the sum of £1,000,000 required for the Grafton to South Brisbane railway, the raising and spending of which is authorized by the Grafton to South Brisbane Railway Act. The total requirements for Commonwealth works, for the Federal Capital Commission, and for redemption loans not otherwise authorized, are thus £11,650,839. This is the amount of the bill now before the committee, and full particulars are set out in the schedule. The chief items of expenditure included in the bill for Commonwealth works, &c, are -
As already explained, the bill also includes £90,340 for loan redemption purposes, and £2,000,000 for the Federal

Capital Commission. Honorable members are aware that the unexpended balances of revenue appropriations at the close of each financial year lapse. The unexpended balances of loan appropriations, however, do not lapse. As a result of this practice there was, until last financial year, a large accumulation of live loan appropriations, many of which could not be used. It was considered advisable to clear up the position by providing in the Loan Act of last year for the lapsing of the unexpended balances then existing under the usual annual loan appropriations of former years. At the same time, provision was made for the full amount of the loan expenditure of last year to be appropriated in the Loan Act of that year. It is proposed to continue this practice. In this way, each year's loan programme can be dealt with as a whole by Parliament when the annual Loan Bill is under consideration. In accordance with this practice, provision is made in the bill now before the committee for the lapsing of the unexpended balances of the appropriations made in last year's Loan Acts. In addition, authority is sought in this bill for the expenditure of the full amount of loan money required for the loan programme of this year. This provision regarding lapsing relates only to the appropriation of loan moneys; it does not relate to the authority given by existing Loan Acts for the borrowing of money. The effect of this is that authority still exists for certain moneys to be. borrowed under the Loan Act of last year, but moneys so borrowed can be spent only for the purposes set out in the bill now before the committee. Towards the programme of loan works for 1926-27 there is a considerable amount of loan money in hand or in sight. These moneys consist of the present loan fund balances and the amounts payable, up to September next, as instalments of the recent London loan of £6,000,000. It will suffice, therefore, if Parliament now gives authority for the Treasurer to borrow £3,500,000 for the purposes of the loan programme for 1926-27. It is not possible to state now the terms and conditions under which further moneys will be raised for works. I may say, however, that it has been definitely decided to borrow in Australia the sum of £2,000,000 required for the Federal Capital Commission. The time for the raising of this money has not yet been decided. This bill does not .provide for conversion or redemption, operations in respect of war loans. Authority for dealing with these conversion operations is contained in existing laws, and it is not necessary to include such redemption operations in the annual Loan Bill. The loan requirements under the migration agreements are not dealt with in this bill, but are provided for in the bill recently passed relating to development and migration. Any information required in regard to the works included in the Loan Bill will be furnished during the course of the debate.
Mr. Mann.Is the Government now borrowing money for the purpose of redeeming loans?

talk.start.para: - That is so. For the redemption of most loans fresh sums are 'borrowed to replace the amount of the loans, less the sum that has been applied to the sinking fund.

.- Referring to the provision of £1,240,000 for railway construction in the Northern Territory and in the northern part of South Australia, I wish to inform the House that I recently travelled along the route of the overland telegraph line from Oodnadatta to the Katherine River, and thence proceeded to Darwin, thus following the proposed route of the north-south railway. I had a good deal of experience as a young man in developing country similar in quality to much of the land along that route. I spent some time in the north-western portion of New South "Wales in developing 250,000 acres of country that is very similar to a good deal of the land between Charlotte Waters and Alice Springs, and north of it. The country of which I had experience in New South Wales is similar to much of the land that I saw on the first 400 miles of my journey northward from the southern boundary of the Northern Territory. Later I had experience as the senior partner in a firm that developed a considerable tract of country in Queensland between Winton and Hughenden, which we fenced, watered, and stocked. This is precisely the same class of country as the Barkly Tablelands. The difference between the area in New South Wales, to which I have referred, and the southern part of the Northern Territory is that, while the former has a rainfall of about 11 or 12 inches per annum, the latter has a rainfall varying from 5^ to 8 inches per annum, little of the country having over 7 inches. I need hardly say that the rainfall makes a great difference in the stock-carrying capacity of the land. There is a tract of very bad to poor country, extending from Oodnadatta to within 50 miles of Newcastle Waters, with two or three patches of good to first class land. One of these patches was on the Burt Plain. It was about 4£ miles across, and was equal in quality to the Barkly Tablelands. Another was Maryvale, south of Alice Springs, and Glen Maggie, north of Alice Springs. The distance through those two patches would be from 30 to 35 miles, so that it may be said that in travelling for 700 miles I saw less than 50 miles of good land. Of this only 4£ miles was first class country capable of carrying a sheep to 2 or 3 acres, and the rest would possibly carry a sheep to 6 or 8 acres. The bulk of the land from Oodnadatta to within 50 miles of Newcastle Waters, with the exception of the patches I have mentioned, would not carry, on the average, more than one sheep to from 20 to 25 acres, or three cattle to the square mile. A good deal of it would not support more than one bullock to the square mile, although some of it would carry five or six to the square mile. On the return journey we travelled through the centre of the Barkly Tablelands, and practically the whole of that country is first class grazing country. I estimate that, when improved and watered, it will carry one sheep to 4 acres, or possibly one sheep to 3 acres.
- What area of such country would be the honorable member say there is on the Barkly Tablelands?

- The area of that country is, I should say, nearly as large as the State of Victoria. I think there must be from 35,000,000 to 40,000,000 acres of that country. That area can only be developed by railway construction to give access to the nearest ports, and if so developed it would carry from 10,000,000 to 12,000,000 sheep; and not less, in my opinion, than 10,000,000 sheep. There is another area which I did not see, but about which I obtained full information from several people, and that is the country west of Barkly Tablelands to the Victoria River, and extending from there into Western Australia. There is between the Barkly Tablelands and the area on the Victoria River something like -100 miles of ordinary cattle country to be crossed. If a railway were constructed from Camooweal through the Barkly Tablelands to Newcastle Waters,, it would, I have no doubt, not immediately, but later on, be extended through the Victoria River country to one of the ports in Western Australia - either Wyndham, Derby, or Broome. In my opinion, such a line is the only one that would properly develop the whole of that rich area of country. I take it that honorable members are agreed that one of the most important matters with which this Parliament has to deal is the development and peopling of the Northern Territory. It is intimately bound up with the defence of the Commonwealth and the maintenance of the White Australia policy. I assume that honorable members will also agree that the right thing to do is to develop first, the good country, and not the bad country. The country from Oodnadatta to within 50 miles of Newcastle Waters is nearly all bad or poor country.
- Did the honorable member go east and west of the line?

- No. I am assuming that what I saw was about the average of the country east and west of the line. I believe that it is so, and I asked a good many questions on the subject. Some people told me that if I had gone off the line I would have seen better country, but others told me that if I had gone off the line, in other places I would have seen worse country. It will be generally admitted that it would be an extraordinary thing if the telegraph line, which we followed, and along which it is proposed the railway should be constructed, should go through only the bad country, and that the country on both sides of the line should be better. The question is whether this Parliament will agree to spend £2,000,000 or £3,000,000 on the first section of the railway from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs.
- Parliament has already agreed to the construction of that line.

- I do not know whether it is possible for Parliament to reconsider its decision in that regard. Perhaps it is not, and if so it is very disappointing ' to know that the money spent upon the construction of the line will be practically wasted. ' If it were spent in developing the Barkly Tablelands we should have some result from it. We should be able to settle a number of prosperous settlers in that country. It would be stocked within a very short time, and after the construction of a railway would carry 10,000,000 sheep or more. A railway from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs will do practically nothing in the way of settling the country through which it will go. I estimate that that country, with 'the exception of the three patches of good country to which I have referred, is so poor that it would take from 150,000 acres to 200,000 acres to give a decent living to one family. We have a railway now to Oodnadatta, and a train once a fortnight is sufficient to cope with all the traffic there. If the line is continued for 300 miles further north, I do not think it will be necessary to run more than one train a month to carry the traffic offering. We are going to spend between £2,000,000 and £3,000,000 on this line to attain this result. It will settle few, if any, people on the land. We have a line now from Darwin to the Katherine River, in length about '200 miles, and its construction has done very little indeed to bring about settlement. Very large tracts of country are still unoccupied along one side of the railway, although the line may be said to go through country quite as good as the bulk of that through which a railway from Oodnadatta to 50 miles south of Newcastle Waters would pass. If the railway from Darwin to Katherine River has not brought about settlement, what reason have we to think that the extension of the Oodnadatta railway through similar country will have a different . result ?
- Would not that' railway connect the country with the Adelaide market ?

- Transport backwards and forwards between the cattle stations would be the only traffic offering for the line. I do not think it would pay any man to fatten cattle on that country and send them to Adelaide by rail. The charges now are so high from Oodnadatta to Adelaide that it is only when the Adelaide market is very good that even prime fat cattle can be sent to that market by rail. Cattle from 300 or 500 miles further north would not be sent by rail to the Adelaide market unless prices offering were exceptionally high. People will travel their cattle, rather than truck them from that distance. I am unable to see how the construction of the proposed line north from Oodnadatta is going to be of any benefit to Adelaide. If the rivers and creeks were bridged, or some means provided to enable them to be crossed by motor traffic, the building of a good road over that country would,' in my opinion, be of quite as much advantage to the few settlers there as would be the construction of the railway.
- How would the honorable member get cattle in or out of that district in drought time without a railway 1
- I do not think that it would pay any one to send cattle by rail through Alice Springs in drought time or any other time. The freight to Adelaide would be something like £4 or £5 per head.
- Nothing like so much.

- The road, as it stands, is fairly good. If the rivers and creeks were bridged and a few patches where there are loose sand-hills were made passable by a corduroy road, that would be all that is necessary, and the cost involved would be infinitesimal compared with the cost of the railway. In my opinion, to build a railway right through from the south to the north through the Northern Territory will cost anything from £15,000,000 to £20,000,000, whilst a good road through the whole district might be constructed for £1,000,000, or less. The greater part of the road is already made, and the bad parts of it could be improved by comparatively little expenditure.
- What about the mineral possibilities of the country?

- There are mineral possibilities, certainly, but I assume that no honorable member will contend that we should build a railway right through that country on the chance of discovering some rich mines. I do not think that would be a business proposition. I discussed the building of the railway and the quality of the country with a number of residents in the Northern Territory. One man, who has been there for 40 years, at Charlotte Waters, assured me that they only get one good season out of three; and that statement was confirmed by others whom I met.
- Where?

- In the country for about 500 miles north of Oodnadatta. The settler to whom I referred told me that the rainfall was about 5£ inches per annum. He said that if they could depend upon getting that rainfall every year in two falls, they could manage to get along; but, unfortunately, there is only about 2-J to 3 inches of effective rainfall, and the balance of the annual fall comes in small falls of 10 or 20 points that do not do any good at all.
- Did the honorable member take the trouble to look at the sheep at Charlotte Waters?

- I looked at the sheep at Brunette Downs, but I do not think there were any sheep at Charlotte Waters, although I have admitted that the Charlotte Waters country is good sheep country. One has to travel something like 700 miles from Oodnadatta to get to the good country. What is proposed is that we should build a railway for 700 miles through bad country; with the exception of 40 miles of country most of which is only fair ,and only one small patch which can be called first-class country. In my opinion, the right thing for Parliament to do would be to develop the Barkly Tablelands first.
