To do that it would be necessary to build a line from Borroloola, a port on the Gulf of Carpentaria. Some expenditure would be required at the port to accommodate deep-sea shipping, but it would not.be very much.
- It would be a very expensive harbour.

- Its improvement would be necessary, but I am advised that that would not involve a great deal of expenditure. Ships call at the port now, and goods are taken to and from them in lighters; and that would be good enough for a time. A railway from Borroloola to tap the Barkly Tablelands would be about 130 miles long. That is the first work that should be undertaken. The Government should construct first the 35 miles from Borroloola, which' at present is impracticable for motor traffic.

speech.para: That section could then connect with good roads, which would serve the settlers until the line was extended to the centre of the Barkly Tableland to connect ultimately with the main railway from Camooweal to Newcastle Waters. Expenditure upon that scheme would bc much saner than the sinking of large sums of money in the construction of the north-south railway. I do not desire to repudiate any agreement made by the Commonwealth with the State of South Australia, but the agreement does not specify any time within which the northsouth railway must be built. The duty of Parliament is to develop the good country first, and the poorer country later, if circumstances justify a large expenditure upon it. I do not know why people have settled in the centre of Australia; but as they were encouraged by successive governments to go there, this Parliament has a responsibility to provide them with decent, well-watered roads. The Government should at the earliest possible date make the road for the whole distance from Oodnadatta to Darwin passable for motor traffic. That could be done at comparatively small cost.

talk.start.para: - The road would compete with the railway when it was constructed.

- The South Australian representatives may be opposed to my suggestion; but leading men in that State with whom I discussed this matter agreed that the north-south line will be a white elephant. Those who have taken the trouble to ascertain the facts know that it will not be the benefit to South Australia that some people expect, and that, on the contrary, the taxpayers of the Commonwealth will have to pay heavily for the enormous losses that it is certain to make. Having seen the country, I am satisfied that the losses will be far heavier than have been estimated. Before I undertook this trip I was prepared to support the north-south railway, but what I saw along the route compelled me to change my opinion. Any practical man who is a judge of the quality of country for pastoral purposes could not help coming to the conclusion that the railway will incur heavy losses for the next 50 years at least. I doubt whether a railway over the first 600 miles north of Oodnadatta will, ever be profitable. The money that will be sunk in it could be spent with greater advantage on the good portions of the Territory, and, manifestly, that is the right policy to adopt. Even at this stage Parliament should pause before it votes money for even the Oodnadatta to Alice Springs section. I am sure that if the line is proceeded with people will declare in a few years that it should never have been built, and that the money spent upon it has been wasted.
- What is the honorable member's view of the railway from a defence point of view?

- If military experts declare that it is necessary for the defence of Australia, I shall not say a word against it; but I believe that motor traffic would meet the requirements of defence as well as, or better than, a railway.
- The military experts support the eastern route across the Barkly Tableland.

- Yes; and I am certain that a line connecting up with .the Queensland system, crossing the Barkly Tableland to Darwin, and ultimately joining up with the Western Australian system, will be a better aid to the defence of the country than will the north-south railway.
- What is the rainfall on the Barkly Tableland?

- It varies from 13 to 16 inches. I believe the average is about the same as on the Queensland Downs, between Longreach and Hughenden, but the rain comes more regularly, and a drought is seldom experienced.
- The rainfall is less variable on the Barkly Tableland.

- Yes, and the country is quite as suitable for sheep as land in Central Queensland that has been profitably grazed for many years past. If the railway were constructed across the Barkly Tableland - and it could be done cheaply, because there are no engineering difficulties - and the country within 20 or 30 miles of the line were subdivided into 20,000-acre blocks, and the country further out into 30,000-acre blocks, it would be rushed by selectors.
- This Parliament made certain that that would not happen when it passed the Northern Territory Administration Act.

- When the railway is built, any country that is required for closer settlement can be resumed by the payment of compensation to the holders of long leases. An expert commission would assuredly advise the Government that the country along the eastern route should be developed by railway construction, and that money should not be squandered on the very inferior country along the central route.
- Does the honorable member refer to the Macdonnell Ranges
- That is second class country.
- How much of it did the honorable member see?

- What I saw is, I am told, average country. It will not carry more than a sheep to 10 or 12 acres, which is a light carrying capacity. I had expected to see exceptionally good country about Alice Springs; hut, although it is better than the areas north and south of that settlement, and has a rainfall of about 11 inches, much of it is hilly and rough, and the average is only of second class grade. The Emily Plain, to the south of Alice Springs, was much commended, but there, again, I saw only second class country. I was told that the Burt Plains comprised a very fine area of 200 miles east and west by a depth of 90 miles, but when travelling through the area I was wondering when we would reach the good part. The best of, it, with the exception of a patch, 4^ miles ; wide, previously referred "to, is second class, and the worst, comprising spinifex and shifting sand-hills, is not better than fifth class. It will be an absolute tragedy if this Parliament expends millions of pounds upon the construction of a railway through that area, and leaves good country elsewhere undeveloped. In travelling, through the Northern Territory, I had no axe to grind ; ' my only object was to judge for myself which of the conflicting opinions regarding the value of the country was right. . Some people declared that it. was first class, and could carry a large white population, and that if it were not settled and populated speedily our ambitious and enterprising neighbours to the north would take it from us. Others declared that the country was a wilderness, and that the less money we spent on it the wiser we would be. My personal investigation convinced me that neither opinion was right. The worst of the country is not a wilderness. There is no desert country, but much of the land is so sparsely grassed that it would carry only one beast to the square mile. Country of that quality is almost a desert. It is not capable qf being even reasonably thickly populated. . I give great credit to the people who are living there; they deserve every consideration from the Government, and every facility that can be provided for them. The first thing to give them is a reasonably good road; and I hope that the Government will provide that for them.

.- I recommend the honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Killen) to read a letter written to one of the Adelaide newspapers by Mr. Giles, a man who has - been esteemed throughout the Northern Territory as a pastoralist for 40, if not 50, years. He read the casual statements of the honorable member, who admits that he travelled only along the route of the telegraph line. Mr. Giles says that in looking for a route for the telegraph line the surveyors must have selected the most barren and worthless part of the country. The construction of that telegraph line was one of the most remarkable achievements by a small State in the history of the world. The route chosen was tho easiest and most direct, and. in travelling along it - and, indeed, in travelling along most of the railways of Australia - ohe does not see the richest parts of the country. The railways of every State pass through a lot of poor country, and generally not through even average country. Mr. Giles is one of the whitest and most honoured men that ever went into the Northern Territory, and when the honorable member for Riverina' reads his column letter he will blush from the top of his head to his toes ; and that will be more than a 6-foot blush; The honorable member did not see fori himself, but he took his opinions' from -persons he met on the route..
- Not at all.

- I ask honorable members whether he did not give them that impression. He said that he' took the direct route, and that he obtained his impressions of the country, except a strip of the Barkly Tablelands, which he could not miss seeing, from others.
- Has the honorable member ever been to the Territory?

- No; but I have many times been through alot of the country described by the honorable member for Riverina, and I shall tell honorable members about it. If I did go through the Territory, God forbid that I, as a responsible member of this House, should tell such a tale as the honorable member has told ! He said, " I was told so," and " I was told so," all through his speech.
- He is a pastoralist.
- I know he is a pastoralist, and that is why I am so astounded at his reckless statements.
- If the honorable member would go and look at the country, he would tell the same tale.

-With his long experience, the honorable member ought to have sense enough to admit that neither he nor any one else is familiar with the character of all the different parts of even his own State. I shall pithily state a few facts, and then ask him whether he thinks he has done good by making such slanderous statements about this part of the country after an "inspection" which he never made. He dealt first with the Oodnadatta country, and in that connexion I want to give honorable members an idea how mischievous his misrepresentations may be, because persons outside this House take statements by honorable members at their face value. The honorable member said, " There is a train once a fortnight," but he should . have said, " There is a passenger train once a fortnight." I shall tell the House what trains there are, and have been for the last 30 years. The cattle season, in good years, is a peak period on the railway. The traffic has dwindled to small dimensions to-day, but it is beginning to improve, because the drought is over. In good seasons, for five, six, or seven months in the year, the line supplies the Melbourne and Adelaide markets with beef.
- And there is one good season in three.

- It also largely supplies the Adelaide market all the year round. For five or six months in the year there are trains night and day, at the end of every week, and during that busy period as many as twenty-five sets of men, and numbers of engines and other rollingstock, on occasions are commandeered from other lines.
- What are the profits of the line?

- One profit is that the line keeps the beef market throughout Australia fairly steady. Without it no one knows what the workers, whom the honorable member represents, would have to pay for meat. The honorable member for Riverina has said that there is one good season in three ; but there is only one good season in three in many of the occupied parts of Queensland and New South Wales.
- But there is a better rainfall there.
- There is not a better rainfall there.
- They have no railways.

- Many of the railways they have do not pay. The honorable member knows nothing of the Oodnadatta country. How can he have any knowledge of it, considering where his experience has been gained? He is an old experienced squatter, and he has stated opinions contrary to those held by the Pastoral Association of South Australia. I challenge him to ascertain the views of the Pastoral Association of Queensland. Let me give him a true bill. The drought of 1896 was probably the worst drought that Australia has ever experienced; it affected nearly the whole of this continent; but at that time Oodnadatta was' a perfect paradise, . with feed 3 feet high. It was my privilege, on behalf of the South Australian Government, to go to that part of the State, and, with the police officers and their black boys, to inspect it to find pasturage for farmers' working horses. The result was that no fewer than 7,000 working draught horses were transferred to that part of the country, and they were returned to their farms the next year very fat. Not one of them would have been left had they remained in the agricultural part of South Australia. That is the country that my honorable friend refers to as " a desert." It certainly is dry country.
- With under 5 inches of rainfall.

- Under 5 inches of rainfall is a good rainfall in many pastoral parts of this country. The honorable member comes from a good rainfall area, and misleads the House. I look upon him with compassion, for when he thinks over this matter he will realize that he has made a great mistake. Admittedly, it is dry country, but the honorable member wishes this House to believe that similar dry conditions exist for another 700 or 800 miles northwards. That is absolutely contrary to fact. I wish to quote other authorities in opposition to the honorable member. One of them is Mr. Manifold, of the Western District of Victoria. Is he not a practical man?
- Did he go over all this part of the country?

- He went over twenty times as much as did the honorable member. He took with him a fellow squatter of the Western District, Mr. Campbell, and the then proprietor of Kirk's Bazaar, a man who has made considerable wealth from his business, and knows a good deal about stock. That party, unlike the honorable member for Riverina, did not follow the telegraph line, but spent six weeks examining the country adjacent to Alice Springs. The rainfall there is from 10 to 22 inches. After a close examination the members of the' party concluded that it was the finest horse-breeding and pastoral country that they had seen.
- Did they ever select any of it?
- They, having made their fortunes, had no reason to select it.
- No man is so rich that he does not wish for more.

- I leave other honorable members and the general public to judge the honorable member's interjections. During the worst drought that South Australia had experienced for 35 years, there was plenty of feed at Alice Springs. The representatives of the Imperial and Indian Governments who from time to time visit Australia to purchase horses know all about that country. They say that it breeds the finest remounts in the world; in fact, the horses there have legs like whalebone.

speech.para: That country saved South Australia during . a financial crisis. If South Australia had had the means the Northern Territory would have been developed years ago.

talk.start.para: - It was lucky for South Australia that the Commonwealth took over the Territory.
- I cannot understand why an honorable member engaged in pastoral pursuits should misrepresent the facts about the Northern Territory. His opinion is valueless.
- The honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Killen) knows more about the pastoral industry than the honorable member does.

- I know more about that country than the honorable member for Forrest does. He is a shrewd insurance agent. I should hesitate to accept his advice, but it would be preferable to that of the honorable member for Riverina. That honorable member stated that the dry country surrounding Oodnadatta was not a desert, but I say that it is at times. There are lots of deserts in Australia, including Queensland. No pastoralist, just because he loses from . 50,000 to 70,000 sheep through drought, abandons his holding. The Macdonnell Ranges is the best horsebreeding country in the world, according to eminent authorities from India and Great Britain. If the honorable member had searched the records of the production of the district between Oodnadatta and Alice Springs, and had read the opinions of eminent pastoralists, he would not have attempted to deceive honorable members with his fairy tales.
- I have spent years developing the. same class of country in New South Wales and Queensland.
- If that is so, the honorable member ought to be ashamed of himself. It is my bounden duty to expose his misrepresentation of the facts concerning the Northern Territory.
- Where did the honorable member gain his experience of pastoral country?

- I had 40 years' experience in South Australia. I know all about the ups and downs of the pastoral industry there. Some 35 years ago I helped to pass legislation through the South Australian Parliament to estab- lish the pastoral industry, by making available grants for wire netting to keep down the ravages of wild dogs. We never begged for wire netting. The South Australian Government lent money to buy wire netting, and it was brought out in ships' bottoms at ballast rates, and settlers repaid principal and interest. The solidarity of South Australia to-day is evidence of what that State knows of the back country and the proper method of developing it.
- That is the best argument that the honorable member has used.

- That State set an example that could, with advantage, be followed by the other States. I am glad to be able to expose the fallacy of the statement of the honorable member for Riverina. Mr. Giles, to whom I have frequently referred, is a man of whom the people of South Australia are proud. The Territorial Association there has 300 members, all of whom are most enthusiastic.
- How many of them have seen the Territory ?

- Most of them. At its next meeting I shall make known the honorable member's description of the Territory. I hope that my speech this afternoon will do much to counteract the harmful influence which the honorable member for Riverina has attempted to exercise inside and outside this chamber, respecting the urgent need to develop the Northern Territory.

. - I listened with interest to the remarks of the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Foster) and his eulogistic references to Mr. Giles, and also to the instructive speech of the honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Killen), to whom honorable members are greatly indebted. At considerable personal inconvenience, he undertook to examine the conditions of the Northern Territory, and he came back with valuable and first-hand information. The honorable member for Wakefield took the honorable member for Riverina to task somewhat severly for referring to the unsuita'bility of the country north of Oodnadatta for pastoral purposes ; but - he himself in his criticism did not indicate the source of his own information, except that it came from some mysterious individual of the name of Giles.
- I have quoted his opinions in this Parliament for the past ten years.

- The House would be well advised to consider the opinions of the honorable member for Riverina. He has undoubtedly gone to considerable trouble to gather valuable information. The House has voted certain moneys for building railways, and if it were possible to reconsider the position, I should strongly advocate the expenditure of money to develop pastoral country, such as the Barkly Tablelands, avoiding altogether any expenditure on country which the honorable member for Wakefield has described as a desert. It is quite possible that the honorable member for Riverina followed the telegraph track, which is, as has been suggested, the ordinary stock route; and although the land along that route may differ from some on each side of it, it would certainly enable one to form some idea of the country generally. The honorable member for Riverina, with his long experience of the pastoral industry, would be well fitted to sift and analyse the opinions given to him by the people living in the district.
- The honorable member for Riverina, on his so-called tour of inspection, was accompanied by four ladies, and the trip was made as quickly as possible.

- That may be so. and I shall deal with that matter in a moment. It has been said that we should honour the agreement between the Commonwealth and South Australia. I am quite willing to honour that obligation, but there is no urgency for the construction of the north-south railway. Our first duty, I submit, is to develop the most valuable land in the Territory, and until we have ' done that, we should not embark upon extravagant expenditure to develop country which, in the opinion of many capable judges, will never be worth very much. If the country from Borroloola,' down to the Barkly Tablelands, and across to Camooweal were provided with a railway as suggested by the honorable member for Riverina, some splendid areas would be opened up for settlement. Seeing that the honorable member for Riverina is a good judge of the value of pastoral land, it is significant that he . estimated that the Macdonnell Range country would not carry one sheep to 10 acres. There is a nigger in this wood pile. The honorable member for Angas (Mr. Parsons) suggested, by a question that he asked to-day, that the Government should almost indecently hasten the construction of the line from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs. We can quite understand the sentiments of honorable members from South Australia in regard to this matter, but that should not cause us to neglect our duty to develop our best country first. I know of large areas that should be opened up long before the Northern Territory is touched.
- Where are they?

- In Central and Western Queensland. They would be tapped by a railway running from the Barkly Tablelands through Camooweal to the terminus of one of the existing Queensland lines. The lives of 7,000,000 sheep in that country could have been saved had facilities been available for removing them during the recent drought to other parts of Queensland where feed and water were available. The very fact that so many sheep were there is evidence of the carrying capacity of the country. Some of the finest sheep in Australia are bred there. Although I do not claim to speak with special knowledge of the Northern Territory, I have taken every opportunity to converse with people who are well acquainted with it by having lived in it for very many years, and also with people who have lived in parts of Queensland that are similar to the Northern Territory. It was a pleasure to me to hear the honor-: able member for Riverina speak so frankly, and I am sure that when the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Foster) has had time for reflection, he will be the first to admit the truth of the sentiments that were expressed.

. - I have no doubt that the honorable member for Riverina was honest in the view that he expressed,- but it must be patent to us all that it is impossible for any one to base a reliable opinion of the Northern Territory on a flying trip through it such as he 'has just made. He travelled' along, the telegraph line, and saw the country at the end of one of the most disastrous droughts it has known.
- The country was looking splendid.

- If it was looking splendid two months after the break of the drought, what will it look like in another twelve months? The honorable member could have seen very little country sitting in a motor car, yet he admitted that he saw some fine strips of land running east and west. In that case, it would surely be reasonable for us to suppose that there is equally good land which the honorable member did not see running north and south. I regret that this matter has been introduced just as South Australia, after many years of waiting, is about to have her patience rewarded by the Commonwealth fulfilling, at least in part, its contractual obligations to her. But, in spite of the honorable member's remarks, I do not for a moment consider that honorable members in this chamber or in another place will reverse their vote for the construction of the Oodnadatta to Alice Springs railway. To do so would be to say, in effect, to the world, "We are such absolute idiots that, although we have just passed a bill authorizing an expenditure of £1,700,000 on a railway from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs, we intend to reverse our decision because one of our members, who has taken a flying trip through the country, does not think it is worth a railway."
- When was the honorable member for Angas last through the country ?

- I lived for six years at Darwin and other places as far south as Pine Creek. With all due respect to the honorable member for Riverina, I intend to pin my faith to the views of men who have lived the greater part of their lives in the Northern Territory, raised families there, seen the varying seasons over a long period of years, and have such unlimited faith in it that they have established their sons there. The honorable member said that he had- conversed with leading men in Adelaide who had confirmed his view that the country in the southern part of the Northern Territory was of no value. I should like to know the names, of some of those gentlemen, although I shall not ask the honorable member to publish them, for that might make it necessary for them to leave South Australia. South Australians, I may tell the honorable member, do not run down their own country or foul their own nest. They have unbounded confidence in the future of their State. It is regrettable that so many Australians can be found who will at any time decry their own country. Only a single word need be said to some people about the Northern Territory to cause them to cry " stinking fish " in a loud voice, and win applause from the crowd for doing so. We should be developing a race of bigger Australians, and honorable members of this Parliament should set an example. To hear some people' discuss the Northern Territory, one would think that it was a more hopeless desert than the Sahara. A good deal of country in the United States of America is similar to the poorer areas in the Northern Territory, but we do not hear the Americans condemning it. They lose no opportunity of telling us that the United States of America is God's own country. We should take a leaf out of their book. If we condemn our country, who will praise it? Although the honorable member for Riverina said by interjection a few moments ago that the drought-stricken country that he passed through was looking splendid, I assure him that it was nothing like so luxuriant as it will be in a few. months' time. It needs two or three rains to bring it into its prime. When people who have seen it at its best have described it to those who live in the settled areas, they have been disbelieved. In my opinion, the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Foster) has a better knowledge of the Northern Territory than any other honorable member of this Parliament. He certainly knows very much more about it than the honorable member for Riverina who has merely made a flying trip through it. I suggest that the honorable member for Riverina should suspend his judgment' for twelve months, and then make another trip through it. I feel sure that he would then admit the truth of the old adage, " Second thoughts are best ".

. - I must express a certain amount of admiration for the honorable member for Riverina for expressing his opinion so candidly. Knowing the vast area of the Northern Territory as I do, I was not surprised to hear his conclusions. It must not be understood that he has totally condemned the Territory, for he said quite frankly that some of the land in the eastern districts of it are equal to the best land in Queensland, and that there are large areas of first class country in its western districts. But his conclusions in regard to the southern areas are, in my opinion, quite erroneous, though he is not by any means the first pastoralist to express such views on a first impression. I feel sure that he, like many others, will alter his views after he has had more experience of the country. The honorable gentleman travelled over a stock route that is traversed by thousands of cattle every year, and is kept in a practically eaten-out condition; and he could have had little opportunity to inspect the country either to his right or left. In brief, his view is that the country in the north, east, and west of the Territory is good, but that that' in the south is not worth the expenditure of public money on it. I have pointed out in this chamber on many occasions that it is impossible for any one to pass reliable judgment on the Territory without a much wider experience of it than can possibly be gained in one brief visit. My first impression of Central Australia was similar to that formed by the honorable member. When I went along the route of the overland telegraph line, I thought it was remarkable that cattle could exist there, but since that time I have availed myself of opportunities to inspect the country for 100 miles or so east and west of that route. When one reaches the sloping country back from the telegraph line, magnificent land is found. Only recently I was at a station that breeds horses that are averaging £38 a head on the Adelaide, market. Will any honorable member suggest that horses commanding that price are not of high quality? In my opinion, Central Australia is quite suitable for the raising of sheep and cattle. Although I realize that it will not be possible to run two or three sheep to the acre, my experience of the country enables me to estimate its carrying capacity as, roughly, one sheep to 6 or 3 acres. Some of the land will carry five or six head of stock to the square mile, and it would be fair to say that it would take one sheep to 5 or 6 acres. It must also be remembered that there are tremendous areas where the breeding of cattle, horses, or sheep can be carried on even in drought periods. I was in Central Australia in November last, before the last drought broke up, and, although the conditions in the northern portions of South Australia were most deplorable, cattle dying in all directions, I did not see one beast in Central Australia that could be described as being in poor condition. This was due to a superabundance of top feed and supplies of sub-artesian water at shallow depths. I do not suggest that this country is the garden of Australia, but I realize that it is capable of producing great wealth in sheep, horses, and cattle, to say nothing of its immense mineral possibilities. I had the pleasure, a couple of weeks ago, of being on what is regarded as an exceedingly small run in Central Australia; its area is something :like 150 square miles. The owner has wisely sacrificed numbers for quality in the breeding of his stock. He has good horses and cattle, and he is getting better financial returns than other land-holders whose runs range up to 2,000 square miles.
- That argument applies in many parts of Australia.

- Yes. So successful has this owner been that in the next few years he will be able to retire. Recently he sent fourteen Clydesdale horses to market, and received as much for them as was paid for a whole trainload of horses dispatched from another station. This shows the false economy practised on some of the big holdings, where quality is sacrificed for quantity. The honorable member for Riverina had a better opportunity of inspecting the northern than the southern portion of the Territory. When passing through the southern part he proceeded along the stock route without deviating east or west.
- I also followed the stock route in the north.
- But there the honorable member travelled east and west to the Barkly Tablelands. Although the honorable member praised that country,

speech.para: I am inclined to think that Central Australia is more suitable for the small man who intends to raise sheep. The Barkly Tablelands are admittedly rich in Flinders and Mitchell grasses, and are supplied with sub-artesian water at depths varying from 200 to 300 feet; but they do not contain a stick of timber. The honorable members knows that, when one crosses that belt on horseback, one is unable for hundreds of miles to find sufficient wood to boil a "billy." It is true that those tablelands are on the edge of the monsoonal belt, and get some rain every year, which cannot be said of Western Queensland ; but I have known periods when the grass there was rank in some places and dead in others, and when there was no top feed for cattle, as there always is in Central Australia. A hundred miles east of Alice Springs one sees the " old man " salt bush growing to a height of from 15 to 20 feet over large areas. During the recent drought - the most severe experienced in the last 30 years - stock was kept fat on the run recently visited by me. The honorable member for Bass (Mr. Jackson) and the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) recently visited this area, and can bear testimony to the truth of the statement that within six weeks of the time when rain fell there recently, prime cattle were sold at Alice Springs at £7 10s. a head. I submit that that is a far better price than is obtained at the northern end of the Territory, where it was recently boasted that £5 a head had been received. I do not suggest that the honorable member for Riverina had an ulterior motive when he spoke as he did this afternoon ; on the other hand , I feel" disposed to applaud him for having had the courage to express his opinion on the country as he saw it. It is most unfortunate, however, that he did not have an opportunity to visit the pick of Central Australia, east and west of the overland telegraph route. Being a pastoralist, he naturally paid most attention to the pastoral possibilities of the Territory; but the promise of success in mining operations should not be overlooked. A week or two ago I inspected various mineral deposits that have been opened up within the last few years. If " shows " not half .as good as these were located in the southern States, hundreds of men would be employed on them; but under present conditions the properties are almost unworkable, particularly base metal propositions. A large capital expenditure is required for the establishment of the necessary plant and for "the carting of flux, coke, and other material required for the treatment of the ore. The railway to be built in the Territory will assist these base metal propositions. I have seen the "shows" of which the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Foster) spoke. I think that I can say, advisedly, that I know a good deal about Central and Northern Australia, because I have travelled hundreds of miles off the beaten tracks. The honorable member is interested in a. silver lead mine, which, if it were located in almost any other part of Australia, would command unlimited capital. Personally, I would not care to invest money in such a venture under existing conditions, because of the isolated position of the field and the high cost of carting mining requisites. I recently inspected the White Range country, where the hills average from 400 to 500 feet in height, are 2 or 3 miles wide, and 7 or 8 miles long. According to assays made by Government officials, the whole of these hills would yield an average return of 8 dwt. of gold to the ton. There is no mine on the Rand in South Africa to compare with this field, and there are others equally rich. The further one goes towards the Tanami district the more promising the prospects become. I am confident that when the railway is extended to Alice Springs, and the carriage of mining machinery is facilitated, there will be the biggest "strike" of gold in the western part of the Territory that Australia has ever known.

talk.start.para: - Would the construction of the line open up that country?

- Yes, because it would enable heavy machinery to be carted within a reasonable distance of that area over the worst portions of the track in the Northern Territory. In South Australia, from Lake Eyre northward, the country is fairly barren, and there is such a scarcity of water that I do not suppose it would carry one sheep to 30 acres.
- It has been settled for 30 years or move.
- Yes, but cartage is most difficult over that country.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6. SO to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: - I have said that the country in the Northern Territory is deceptive from the pastoral point of view. Men who have visited the Territory have lauded certain areas as great pastoral country, and condemned other areas as poor country, and I have known that the areas condemned were really good country, and" those praised were indifferent country. The honorable member for Riverina compared the areas adjacent to the railway between Darwin and the Katherine River with the very poor country at the southern end of the Territory, which, in his opinion, is useless country. I can inform him that there is a great difference between the carrying capacities of these areas. In the northern areas referred to the grasses grow to a height of from 12 to 14 feet, and the pastoralistwho puts stock into that country can only expect them to die, because it is impossible for them to live on those grasses. That country cannot be compared with the country in the southern part of the Territory, which appeared to the honorable member to be valueless. No one going through that southern part of the Territory, even though it may be after a number of bad seasons, will find poor horses or cattle, and it is obvious that if horses and cattle can be kept in good condition during trying seasons, the land must have some considerable value. I know that after a number of years of scanty rainfall, and within six weeks of a fall of rain, fat cattle were marketed from that part of the Territory. The conclusion at which the honorable member for Riverina has arrived is that the Government would not be justified iu constructing the line from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs. He prefers that it should devote its energy and expenditure to the construction of a line running up from Bourke through New South Wales and the western areas of Queensland to Camooweal, and thence westward to Newcastle Waters.
- I also recommended the construction of a good main road.

- I agree with the honorable member as to the advantage of the construction of such a line as that to which he referred, and I also agree with the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) and that that line should be continued through the western portion of the Northern Territory into the northwest of Western Australia. If such a Hue had been constructed, it would have prevented the loss of stock to the value of millions of pounds. It was very gratifying to hear such an expert in pastoral matters as the honorable member for Riverina telling the House the value of the country through which such a line would pass.
- Would the adoption of that suggestion mean the construction of two lines?

- Tes. The northsouth line is the one under discussion, and the honorable member for Riverina suggested the construction of a line running east and west, and crossing the north-south line in the northern part of the Territory.
- The construction of such a line has been the intention for 30 years past.

- That is so. The value of that line does not detract in any way from the merits of the extension of the north-south line from Oodnadatta northwards. I believe the construction of a line across to Wyndham is essential; but what we are concerned about is the development of the Northern Territory, and to confine our efforts to the northern part would be a fatal mistake. The honorable member for Riverina, on the track on which he travelled over the Macdonnell Ranges, met with a good deal of rocky country after passing Alice Springs, which would not be likely to favorably impress any one, but if he had deviated from the line east and west for from 50 to 100 miles, as he did in the northern part of the Territory, the carrying capacity of the country he would have been able to see would have been a revelation to him, and he would have returned from the Territory with an opinion of its resources very different from that which he has expressed this afternoon.
- Is it not a fact that in other parts of the Territory the country east and west of the overland route is much worse than the country on the route itself? I was told that that is the case.

- I can speak of the country from the experience of settlers within the last five years. The impres sion was held, and is still held, that the country east and west of the north-south line in the central part of the Territory is more or less desert country. But a reference to the records of the Lands Department showing the lands taken up in that area during the last five years is sufficient to refute the statement that that country is worthless. There is a great deal of spinifex country there, but it is soft spinifex, and that is not bad country for cattle. I know some young men who settled in the Central Australia country within the last four or five years and are to-day in a position to sign a very substantial cheque. They started without capital, their only assets being their hands and the will to conquer; and they have conquered. Some of them are here now, looking for other young fellows to go back with them on the share system. They have found that under present conditions the cost of dog-netting their areas is prohibitive. They have found also that it is useless to employ the aborigines as they cannot be trusted. One settler found that with the employment of aboriginals his annual natural increase was about 27 per cent. When he dispensed with native labour and he and his partner took turn about at shepherding, the natural increase rose in one year to about 60 per cent. These men are satisfied that the country on which they are settled is sheep country. In the Arltunga district a man named Cavanagh has made a fortune out of sheep. He did not go in for a very extensive flock, but a flock of 5,000 or 6,000 that he could manage. It is proved that the country is sheep country. I do not say that it has a great carrying capacity, but the areas available are vast, and there is room for the settlement of hundreds of settlers. With sympathetic treatment from the Government, much greater production might be anticipated from that Central Australia country. The Government might undertake to dog-net 50,000 or 100,000 square miles of that country and subdivide it for settlement, because the dingoes are the big menace to stock there. Owing to the high freight on all material required for fencing, the cost is prohibitive for individual settlers.
- That was tried at Mataranka.
- The honorable member says that sheep raising was tried at

speech.para: Mataranka, which is in the northern part of the Territory, where it is a common thing to see grass from 15 feet to 18 feet high. As a sheep man the honorable member knows that with spear grass growing to that height, the country is not suitable for sheep. I have always contended that the northern part of the Territory is not sheep country, and the fact that settlers failed with sheep at Mataranka does not prove that sheep cannot be successfully grazed in other parts of the Northern Territory. A settler named Nickers on the overland track told the honorable member that the country was fairly good, but what did that same gentleman tell the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) when he visited the Northern Territory? He told that honorable member that at the time he was holding something like 2,000 square miles of country; but that if the Commonwealth Government would do for him what was being done for settlers in Queensland and would give him wire netting at a reasonable cost, spreading the payment for it over a number of years, and assist him in providing water, he would select 20,000 acres from his area of 2,000 square miles, would go in for sheep, and would never look back.

talk.start.para: - And he said also that the Government could take the rest of his area.

- I want to say that the area occupied by Nickers is not an exceptional area in that part of the country. I admit quite frankly that if I had known the work that is being done to-day by motor transport, I doubt that I should have advocated the construction of the railway from Oodnadatta to Alice . The motor car and motor truck are mobile vehicles. They are not confined to a definite track as a train is, but can deviate from the main track to any place at which loading is to be obtained. In view of the development of motor traffic in the Northern Territory, one is justified in questioning the wisdom of the construction of the proposed line. If the amount which the Government contemplate expending on the construction of the railway were put into a bank and the interest on it used in the construction of roads throughout the country it would be possible to open up, not merely the northsouth route, but also eastern and western routes in the Northern Territory, and the capital would remain intact in the bank. I would agree entirely with the honorable member were it not for the necessity for transporting fat stock, which causes me to hesitate in advocating motor transport as a complete substitute for railways. I have recently met pastoralists who had stock too fat to travel on the roads, and it would mean much to those men if they could entrain their cattle and deliver them in sound condition. When buyers were paying £7 10s. a head for cattle at Alice Springs, they knew they would obtain £15 or £16 a head for the same beasts at Adelaide. If it is decided to substitute droving for railway transport, a vast improvement must be made in the stock routes. It is no wonder that Central Australia has a bad name for its cattle. The honorable member for Riverina and the honorable member for Bass will admit that the stock driven recently from Central Australia to the head of the railway at Oodnadatta, and thence taken by rail to Adelaide, had to travel for three weeks with three drinks of water. Is it possible to land stock in good condition if they have only three drinks of water in three weeks ? Such, however, are the conditions provided by the Government on the stock routes of the Territory. It is true that there are wells here and there, and that they are all right for one mob of cattle; but, when the droving season arrives, tens of thousands of cattle are travelling. The first mob at a well has a drink, the second mob has only half a drink, and the third mob has to wait four days for half a drink. The Government does not seem to appreciate the vastness of the Territory and the difficulties under which settlement is being attempted. Persons who travel in a motor car from well to well may think that there is plenty of water; but let them mount an old horse, tail up a mob of bullocks, and drive them to the wells under existing conditions. They would then have a different tale to tell. The country is in a deplorable state, not because of its unproductivity, but because of the bad stretch between Oodnadatta and Charlotte Waters, which is severe on travelling stock, and injures the reputation of the pastoral industry in tho

speech.para: Territory. If cattle have to travel for three weeks with only three drinks of water, how much worse would the conditions be for sheep, lt is a recognized fact -.that cattle travel twice as fast as sheep, *o that sheep would have to travel for six weeks on three drinks of water. Those drawbacks could be removed if the Government would deal justly with the pioneers who are doing the spade work of development. If -there were good stock routes, with abundance of water, T would favour a policy of road construction rather than railway construction; but, with the existing policy, or lack of policy, the railway is the only' safe way. Although the argument of the honorable member is good as applied to the pastoral industry, it is not applicable to industries that require machinery and other materials not used by the pastoralists. Here, again, one sees the short-sighted policy of the Government. The railway is to be constructed, but the Government is making no preparation for the development of the country through which it will pass. The promotion of general development should be an adjunct to a railway policy; the two should go hand in glove. We should not just build a railway, and afterwards mourn the losses on it. If tha Government is serious in its developmental policy, it still has ample time to put the country into a state of productivity ready for when the railway is completed to Alice Springs. Mining is one of the industries that should be promoted now, but there is little prospect of doing anything in that direction during the discussion of the Estimates. The Estimates include an item of £400 for the encouragement of the mining industry in the whole of the territory. Any man who knows anything about mining knows that to sink a prospecting shaft costs about £6 a foot. Therefore, a £400 subsidy on a £1 for £1 basis would provide for about 133$ feet of shaft-sinking. Imagine seriously attempting to develop mining in a territory of 500,000 square miles with 133$ feet of shaft ! But that, nevertheless, is the Go.vernment's idea of encouraging mining in the Northern Territory. Unfortunately, the Government has lost sight of the things which are material to the development of the territory. The freight on benzine from Quorn to the head of the railway is £8 0s. 8d. per ton. On the same basis it will cost from £16 to £18 a ton from Quorn to Alice Springs, or about £47 a ton to transport Commonwealth Oil Refineries spirit from Melbourne to Alice Springs. Development under such conditions is impossible. All these things must be taken into consideration in any development policy. I do not wish to deal severely with the honorable member for Riverina. I realize that he placed before this- House his honest convictions, and all 1 regret is that he had not the opportunity of seeing more of central Australia. I am convinced that if he had seen more of it his honest and candid criticism of the country would have been different. I am gratified that he was more than pleased with the possibilities of vast areas of the Barkly Tablelands, and was impressed with what he heard of the western territory. I hope that the debate to-day will be an incentive for honorable members to acquire first-hand knowledge of the Territory. I am convinced that the more knowledge honorable members acquire, the more attention this Parliament will pay to the development of that part of Australia.

talk.start.para: .- The honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Killen) has re-opened a subject that has often been debated in this Chamber - the wisdom or otherwise of constructing the line from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs. It should be obvious to all honorable members that no debate can alter the fact that this Parliament has already authorized the construction of the line; but, notwithstanding that, the honorable member should be commended for bringing the subject of the development of the Northern Territory again before the House. Having just returned from a visit to that very interesting part of Australia, I should like to touch upon one or two matters regarding the productivity of the Macdonnell Range country, that has been debated somewhat vigorously by the honorable member for Wakefield, and by others. I should not care to pit my pastoral experience against that of the honorable member for Riverina, for I believe that he is better qualified to speak on pastoral subjects than most members of this House. Nevertheless, I have had some experience in developing outback country, and I have had the added experience gained during two visits to the

speech.para: Northern Territory. I saw it on one occasion under what I understood were adverse conditions, and I saw it on the last occasion under more favorable conditions. I stayed some days at Alice Springs, and in the Macdonnell Range, and travelled hundreds of miles westwards into the country. The honorable member, in my opinion, took a somewhat pessimistic view of the possibilities of development. As the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson) has 'said, to go through the country in a motor car. travelling rapidly along the stock routes, and to trust to the information gained from the few persons one meets on the track, is not always the most reliable way of ascertaining the possibilities of the country. I have always said that the obligation to build the north-south line existed, and should be honoured ; and, in saying that, I had no axe to grind. I would fight for the development of my own constituency as vigorously as any honorable member would fight for that of his, but at times I try to look beyond it. I have always taken an impartial and active interest in the Commonwealth's obligations respecting the building of the north-south line, and the establishment of the Federal Capital, I think that the building of a railway from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs is justified. When visiting the Northern Territory, I, like the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson), was very much impressed with the possibilities of motor transport. Some two and a half years ago, in the capacity of Minister for Works and Railways, I toured that country by motor car, and the trip was regarded somewhat in the nature of an adventure. Last month I again visited the territory, and found that the trip from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs is an every day occurrence, not in light motor cars, but in heavy motor trucks, carrying at times loads of over two tons, and travelling, on good patches of road, faster than some railway trains, certainly faster than the train from Marree to Oodnadatta. I agree with what the honorable member for the Northern Territory said, and I hope that the Minister will take note of his appeal for' the improvement of that road. Of the stretch of 350 miles over which the motor trucks travel, 330 miles is passably good. The remaining 20 miles is the cause of. all the trouble, and it would not need a large sum of money to repair the bad patchesof road. I suggest that the Government send an officer there to ascertain the bad patches of road, and, by expending a little money in improving them, confer a boon upon the residents of the territory. If the road were improved, the motor owners could rightly be asked to reduce freights a little, and I feel sure that they would agree to do so. Motor transport will be an important factor in lessening the loss on the railway when it is constructed, because the motor vehicles will act as feeders, to the railhead at Alice Springs. I understood the honorable member for Riverina to say that cattle would not be trucked over this line when constructed. I do not agree with him. On both my visits to the territory, I discussed the trucking of cattle with the cattle men. They told me that cattle that were prime at Alice Springs, were stores when they reached Oodnadatta, because of the lack of water and feed on the route. Nothing will reduce the condition of a beast more quickly than lack of water. The cattle men of the Macdonnell Range country are in effect breeders of store cattle. Their cattle never reach the Adelaide market in prime condition. When the railway from Oodnadatta to AliceSprings has been built, I believe thatnearly all the cattle in that country will1 be trucked to the southern markets.

talk.start.para: - Only if the market is attractive. *

- Port Augusta is a magnificent port, and facilities could be established there for the export of beef. That would be a second string to the bow of the cattle men of the territory. They complained bitterly to the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson), the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Jackson), and myself, about the lack of water along the stock route. The Government has stated that a considerable sum of money has already been expended in sinking, bores for water. That may be so, but the settlers, rightly or wrongly, are almost unanimous that the Government's policy has been wrong, because the bores have not been drilled deep enough. In some cases the bores were sunk to 150 feet, at considerable expense, and the plant, for some unknown reason, was removed somewhere else.
- Did not one contractor offer to drill 100 feet for nothing if the

speech.para: Government would pay the cost of drilling another 100 feet?

talk.start.para: - One contractor, a Mr. Horwood, was so confident that water could be obtained that after drilling for 350 feet he said that if the Government would pay for drilling another 100 feet he would drill a similar distance for nothing. The Government should make a searching inquiry respecting the policy of those controlling water boring operations. I have always held the opinion that the water conservation policy for the Northern Territory was wrong, because of insufFicient attention being paid to the conservation of surface water by the construction of dams and the like. Throughout the Macdonnell Range country there are possibilities of water conservation. I know what has been done in this direction in the Mallee country of Victoria, and I suggest that the Government should borrow the services of some of the engineers of the State Rivers and Water Supply Commission of Victoria, who have been responsible for the reticulation of the Mallee country. That scheme consists of the conservation of the waters of the Grampians in a lake there, and their reticulation for a distance of 200 miles as the crow flies through the arid and sandy country adjacent to the River Murray. That is one of the most remarkable and successful schemes of water conservation in the world. If the engineers responsible for that work were sent to the Macdonnell Ranges for three or four months and instructed to report freely on the conservation of surface waters there, I am satisfied that it would be time and money well spent.
- Is there not a great amount of evaporation in that country?

- Undoubtedly the evaporation is great, but it is not great enough to prevent the conservation of water. Water is conserved at Broken Hill, and the honorable member knows that there is not much difference between the evaporation at Broken Hill and that at Alice Springs.
- The difference is in favour of Alice Springs.

- That is so, because the rainfall at the Macdonnell Ranges, being of a monsoonal nature, is better for catchment purposes. The railway from Marree to Oodnadatta is not in a good state of repair. The new locomotives that have been ordered, are too heavy for the line, and their speed is limited to 25 miles an hour because of the bad state of the permanent way. The Algebuckina bridge is a remarkable structure, but because the new locomotives are unable to cross it a deviation of the line has been made.
- South Australia has always regretted building that bridge; a level crossing should be there.

- The honorable member is, perhaps, right; but the bridge is there and the locomotives are unable to cross it. A low level crossing has now been constructed at that point. The provision of both of those works has cost the taxpayers a great deal of money. It is rumoured that the Government intends to strengthen that bridge. Honorable members should be informed of the cost of the deviation and of the proposed repairs to the bridge.
- It is proposed to strengthen the bridge. For years we have known that it would require strengthening to take the extra traffic that will pass over it from the new line.
- Did the estimate of the construction of the railway from, Oodnadatta to Alice Springs include repairs to the existing line?
- I think not.
- It would be interesting to know the cost of putting the existing line in a good state of repair.
- It would be a big item.

- It would be a big item indeed, and the House should be informed of it. The differences of opinion that have been expressed to-day emphasize once more the necessity for the appointment of some permanent committee of this House, on the lines of our existing committees, to inquire into developmental schemes, quite distinct from the Public Works Committee and \he Development and Migration Commission. Honorable members have the responsibility of voting millions of pounds for various works and railway construction about which the majority of them know little, and the few honorable members that know anything at all are at sixes and sevens respecting the wisdom of the expenditure. I cannot resume my seat without paying a tribute to the work of the pioneers in our out-back country. They deserve well of this Parliament, and the Government should do whatever it can to make their lot easier. They do not ask for statues, band rotundas, lawns, or anything of that kind; all that they want is a stock route, a decent water supply, a moderately good road to enable them to reach the centres of civilization occasionally, and medical facilities. It is a reflection upon the Government that it has not long ago provided a medical practitioner for Alice Springs. The nearest doctor to that far-away inland town is at Oodnadatta, which is 300 miles south, and his only means of conveyance is the camel. The Government refused to provide £1,000 on the estimates to meet the expenses of settling a doctor at Alice Springs, on the ground that there might not be sufficient work to keep him fully occupied. The result has been that white women will not live there, and a halfcaste problem has grown up which will later cause the Government a great deal of trouble.
- Another body has now established a hospital there.

- I give every .credit to the Australian Inland Mission for providing the hospital there, which the Government should have established many years ago. I urge the Minister to give a liberal interpretation to every request that the people in the far interior make for medical attention, water supplies, and roads. Every facility should be given to honorable members of this Parliament to visit central and northern Australia. When the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Jackson) and I wished to visit Alice Springs recently, we had to press our claim for travelling concessions. We did not ask for a special motor car, but merely for a pass that would entitle us to travel on the 2- ton lorry that plies regularly between Oodnadatta and Alice Springs. I think I am entitled to say that it was only when we intimated that we could rightly demand a trip to Port Darwin and back, which would have cost four or five times as much as a trip to Alice Springs, that our request was granted. I understand that the trip which the honorable member for Riverina has just concluded cost him over £100.
- That is a shame.

- It certainly is not right. I do not say that honorable members should be entitled to hire a motor car and take a trip to the Territory whenever they have a passing fancy to do so, but I certainly contend that they should be granted facilities to travel on any regular conveyance to the interior. If the members of this Parliament had a better knowledge of the needs of the far north they would make fewer mistakes in legislating for it. If a railway is put through to the Macdonnell Range country, I believe that the story of pioneer settlement in the Mallee will be repeated there.
- What does the honorable member think of the possibility of sheep raising in the Macdonnell Range country ?

- Given a railway, I have no doubt whatever that sheep will replace cattle there. One reason that they are not there at present is that it is too difficult to get them in and out; and another is that before sheep can be managed, fences and water provision are necessary. It is impossible to carry wire netting or scoops and ploughs on the backs of camels. Soon after the railway is operating, sheep raising will be undertaken in a substantial way in the Macdonnell Range country. The railway, in my opinion, is thoroughly justified; but, pending its construction, I urge the Go- vernrnent to give every consideration to providing water schemes, roads, and medical facilities for the pioneers there. It is a peculiar thing that it is possible to determine the attitude of practically every honorable member on this matter by merely ascertaining the State that he represents. If we listened only to honorable members who represent South Australian constituencies, we should come to, the conclusion that the Northern Territory is a magnificent country, while honorable members who represent constituencies in New South Wales and Queensland assure us that parts of it are all right, but that it should not be developed from the southern end. I represent a Victorian constituency, and I have no axe to grind. In ray opinion, the Government is making no mistake in: seeking to develop the Territory from the southern end.

.- I listened with keen attention to the remarks of the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart). Although I have always been, and still am, of the opinion that the Commonwealth should honour its pledge to South Australia, my idea of the value of the country from Marree to Oodnadatta has been considerably changed by a visit I have paid to it. I regret to say that those parts of Central Australia that I have seen are not nearly so fertile as I was led to believe they were.
- The honorable member has not yet seen Central Australia.

- I admit at once that I have not been beyond Oodnadatta; but, as my opinion is unlikely to affect the construction of the railway from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs, I must say frankly that, although I have seen a good deal of what is called the desert country of Australia, the country between Marree and Oodnadatta is the poorest I have seen anywhere. Whatever its condition may have been years ago, it has been destroyed by overstocking. Prom Hawker onwards, properties are pointed out that years ago carried 40,000," 50,000, and up to 100,000 sheep, which to-day are not carrying onetenth as many. The salt bush there has been completely eaten out, and the country is now a wind-swept waste. I wish to make it quite clear that I am not -speaking of the Northern Territory, but of the wilderness between Marree and Oodnadatta.
- That is a reflection upon the constituency of the honorable member for Grey (Mr. Lacey).

- The honorable member for Grey is something of a pioneer in this House in that he is trying to unlock what is now a desert. I have a good deal of sympathy with him. The truth about this country is to be found somewhere between the pessimistic views that the honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Killen) holds of it - though Ave must, oi necessity, pay a good deal of deference to his opinion - and the optimistic estimate of it of the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Foster), who would lead us to believe that it is not necessary to die to get to Paradise, but merely to travel north from Oodnadatta. The suggestion made by the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart), that honorable members should be given every facility to visit the interior of Australia without heavy expense to themselves, is well worthy of the earnest consideration of the Government. Honorable members are expected to vote huge sums of money for developmental works in these areas, and if they had a little personal knowledge of the country they would be able to spend the public money much more intelligently than they can possibly do now. It is remarkable that only two or three honorable members of this House have traversed the continent from north to south. In the circumstances, it cannot be expected that public money will be spent to the best advantage. I can understand the warmth of the honorable member for the Northern Territory in discussing this matter, for I was one of a party which contemplated a trip to the Northern Territory some eighteen months ago under his guidance. For some reason which has never been disclosed, the motor cars that were to have been used by the party were not made available. It has been suggested that the Federal Government should take over the north-weSt of Western Australia, and that it, together with the Northern Territory and a considerable area of northern Queensland, should be controlled by this Parliament. The reason that the Government of Western Australia ia not willing to hand over that part of its territory to the Commonwealth is that it is afraid that the same wasteful expenditure of public money may occur there that has occurred in the Northern Territory, and that there will be just as little to show for it. Although the Western Australian Government has spent less than one-third as much in the north-west of Western Australia as this Government has spent in the Northern Territory, it has established a meatworks there, and has done something towards providing a regular service of steamers. The responsibility for lack of an air service must be laid at the door of the Federal Government.
- The meat-works at Wyndham have saved the Northern Territory and the north-west portion of Western Australia at times.

- Yes; and I respectfully suggest that the Government should take the earliest opportunity of sending a party of such ardent inquirers as the honorable members for Wimmera and Riverina to inspect the country between Darwin, Broome, Derby, and Wyndham, no portion of which has a rainfall of less than 20 inches per annum. I hope that in the near future that country will be under the control of this Parliament. The settlers should be given a voice in the government of that area, by the establishment of an administration somewhat on the lines of the advisory council in Papua, or on the lines on which the Crown colony of Hongkong is governed. There are men in the Northern Territory who, having lived there for years, love it just as others are devoted to the southern parts of Australia, and commissioners of that type could he depended upon to see to its successful development.

.- I think that my views on the subject of the Northern Territory are well known both inside and outside this House, since I have expressed them on many occasions in various parts of the Commonwealth. After a second visit last month to the Macdonnell Ranges I have no reason to alter the opinion that I formed five years ago, supported by the evidence given before the, section of the Public Works Commitee of which I was a member. I have stated on many occasions that I did not support the construction of the north-south railway because of the pledge made to South Australia. I am in the same position as the honorable member for Wimmera. Since my constituency is in the State of Tasmania, I, unlike honorable members from South Australia and Queensland, cannot be regarded as biased. Although I respect the judgment of the honorable member for Riverina, I must set against it the opinion of men who have made money out of the Territory. I shall only mention one of them, Sir Sidney Kidman, who stated to the Public Works Committee that there was no better sheep land in Australia than that in the Macdonnell Ranges. I believe that that country will be developed by sheep-raising, and that the Government would do well to follow the advice of the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) in regard to water surveys. Oh my way to Alice Springs recently I met a gentleman who went to the Northern Territory 23 years ago. He has made money out of cattle and sheep, and he told me that the wells between Oodnadatta and Alice Springs were in a worse condition now than they were in when he first settled in that country. Five years ago it was the duty of a well-repairing party to see that the Government wells were kept in order; but no such arrangement exists to-day. The wells are supposed to be kept in repair by contract. On reaching a well north of Alice Springs recently, a mob of cattle was unable to obtain water because of the large number of stock that required a drink. They had to travel to the next watering place, which was at Burt Well. There is was found that the bucket was at the bottom of the well, and when it was recovered the drover noticed that there was a hole in the bottom of it.
- The rope was broken and worn out.

- The settler had only one eye, and he had the misfortune to injure it through a piece of the rope striking it.For three days he was unableto use his eye; but I am pleased to say that the sight is now unimpaired. There is no proper care of the wells in the Northern Territory.
- That is a serious reflection on the Government.
- Does the honorable member suggest that those wells are not kept in good order?
- Yes ; I say that definitely.
- I am equally definite in stating that the wells to which the honorable member has referred, were put in through repair less than twelve months ago.

- I say, emphatically, that they were not in good order three weeks ago. Since thearea under consideration is over 500,000 square miles, no single railway could develop it. I agree with the honorable member for

speech.para: Riverina that a line should be constructed across the Barkly Tablelands into Queensland. I have always held that view. A perusal of the Public Works Committee's report in 1922 will show that that body first recommended the construction of a line through that country, and then a railway from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs. But the honorable member will do nothing towards the development of the Territory by advocating that it should be opened up by means of a motor road. As to the present motor traffic, it is time that a motor road was declared; waggons could still use the old track. There are only a few spots at which some of the rivers could be crossed, particularly the Finke and the Hugh. I had the experience on my return journey recently of being stuck with a motor car in the middle of one of the sandiest stretches, because a drover had his cattle resting, at the very spot where a dry river bed had t.o be crossed. It is high, time notices were erected warning drovers that they should take cattle across at some other point. The honorable member for Riverina is credited with having said that owners will not truck cattle from Alice Springs, but I point out that in almost every instance the sworn evidence submitted to the Works Committee was that they would certainly take advantage of railway transport, because it would pay them better to obtain high prices for good meat in the Adelaide market than to send down store cattle. I hope that the item will be passed as printed.

talk.start.para: .- I am rather reluctant to re-open a subject that has been discussed on so many occasions as has the north-south railway. My only reason for rising is to reply to some of the remarks of the honorable member for Riverina. We now find that honorable members are not disputing the agreement made with South Australia so much as they are trying to prevent by every other possible means the building of the line. Great credit is due to the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Jackson) and other honorable members who have visited the Territory and expressed an unbiased opinion concerning it. But some honorable members take every opportunity of advocating the construction of a line other than on the direct north-south route. In my opinion some of their statements are incorrect.

speech.para: A few days ago a motion tabled by an honorable member from New South Wales was under consideration. He wished to obtain an advantage by a deviation through his State. A representative of Western Australia is also trying to get a "cut" for that State. The honorable member for Riverina, I am satisfied, went to the Northern Territory with his opinion already formed, and he has taken a biased view of the potentialities of the country. I have inspected a good deal of the vast area traversed by him. It is true that owing to drought conditions, and because of a large accumulation of stock in the neighbourhood of Oodnadatta, the country immediately around that centre is eaten out, and is to some extent a desert ; but it must be remembered that in 1906 the lower portion of the Northern Territory saved the stock of a large number of farmers in South Australia. My brother went to the Northern Territory at that time with stock because of the drought in South Australia. The condition of the country then was the reverse of what it is to-day. I do not wish to discuss this matter at great length to-night,, but I should like to say that those who favour the construction of the line have nothing to fear. The bill authorizing its construction was passed by this House, and the agreements of 1910 and of last year have been ratified by this Parliament. To-day the survey of the line is being made, and I hope that in the very near future its construction will be begun. The honorable member for Riverina stated that the country between Oodnadatta and Alice Springs is of a very poor nature.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member said that for 700 miles it is of a poor nature.

- The honorable member's description might, perhaps, be applied to the country for the first 50 or 100 miles north of Oodnadatta, but beyond that up to Alice Springs the character of the country gradually improves. The honorable member travelled over the stock route, and did not leave it to see what the country on either side was like. He is, therefore, not in a position to give a reliable report of its character. If he had taken the trouble, south of Alice Springs, as he did further north, to inspect the country on either side of the stock route, he would have reported quite differently about it. When I visited the Northern Territory last year, I departed from the stock route on the journey from Oodnadatta to Alice Springs, and I am convinced that the party of which I was a member would have been deceived as to the character of the country if it had remained on the stock route. The honorable member told us that the country around Alice Springs is of a mountainous and rocky nature, but for the information of honorable members who have not been there, I may say that for 12 miles north of Alice Springs the country is rocky and hilly, but after that you reach the fringe of Burt Plain, which extends for miles. The statements of the honorable member for Riverina would lead to the impression that the whole of the country around Alice Springs is rocky and hilly, and unsuitable for grazing.
- I said that it is all second class country or worse, and I still say so.

- I do not agree with the honorable member. Immediately you get through the hilly country around Alice Springs you reach first class pastoral country. If it were not so far removed from centres of population some of that country might be devoted to the cultivation of wheat.
- If it had a proper rainfall.

- The Minister for Works and Railways (Mr. Hill) will, I think, bear me out when I say that when we visited the Territory in 1924 we were told that the rainfall of the district I refer to was 121/2 inches per annum.
- The average annual rainfall at Alice Springs for the last 45 years is 11 inches.

- Provided that the annual fall does not occur in one shower, the honorable member for Riverina and the honorable member for Wimmera will admit that a rainfall of 11 inches is sufficient for the production of wheat.
