- Unfortunately, the rain does not come at the time of the year suitable for the production of wheat. The country is good wheat-growing country if the rainfall were suitable.

- I am contending that it is good pastoral country. We saw sheep in that part of the Territory looking quite as well as sheep to be seen in other parts of Australia. We had to drive the animals out of high grass in order to secure a photograph of a very fine flock of sheep at Ryan's Well. What I have heard the honorable member for Riverina say about that country has made me wonder how much reliance can be placed upon his description of portions of the Northern Territory that I have not had the good fortune to visit. His pessimistic observations need not be taken seriously, in view of the opinions which have been expressed by uninterested persons like the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) and the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Jackson) and others who have visited the Northern Territory. It has been said that the one thing that is necessary is a better supply of water on the stock route. When I visited the Territory, the Wells on the stock route were in good order, hut there was not a sufficient number of them. Going up, we passed a mob of 561 cattle, and repassed the same mob twelve or fifteen days later. During that time these cattle had to go six days without water. That may seem to some honorable members to be extraordinary, but because of the heavy dews' and the fodder available it is possible in that locality to drove cattle six days without water. During the time mentioned the depreciation in the value of the cattle amounted to from 30s. to . £2 per head. The wells on the stock route should be kept in good order, and a greater number should be sunk. In reply to the opinions expressed by the honorable member for Riverina, I wish to place On record the views of other people who are acquainted with the conditions in the Northern Territory. The honorable member suggested that a committee should be appointed to inquire into the character of the country before the railway is constructed. Let me remind him that that has already been done. As a matter of fact, more than one committee has reported on this project. The report with which this House is most concerned is that of the Public Works Committee. In 1922 that committee took extensive evidence, and some of its members travelled over a great portion of the Territory. It presented a report to this Parliament recommending the construction of the railway. From the report I propose to quote the opinions of some pastoralists as to the character of the country. Mr. P. V. Ambrose, a pastoralist, gave the following evidence: -

quote.para: Our lease demands that we should carry one beast to the mile. When we came here in 1912 we had 1,168 cattle, and now we have approximately 4,000, and have sent away a mob every year. We could carry more stock if we had more water, as the feed for a greater number of stock is available. A railway would benefit us whatever route it took, provided it came to within 200 or 300 miles of us. At present we get our supplies from Oodnadatta, although Katherine is nearer. The railway that would bring most settlement would be one from the south, because it is more fit for stocking purposes than the northern end.

speech.para: Here is a pastoralist living in the Northern Territory who has no interest in the southern end, and yet he expresses the opinion that the southern part of the Territory is more suitable than the northern end for stock. That refutes the testimony of the honorable member for Riverina. Another witness, Mr. Alfred John Cotton, a grazier in the Northern Territory, and also a grazier in Queensland, expressed the opinion that if a railway were built the Territory would be developed as other parts of Australia have been developed, and he said -

quote.para: Take, for instance, the railway from Hughenden to Cloncurry. I remember travelling over this route before the railway was built, when you could count the number of settlers on your fingers. Now since the railway has been built there are very many hundreds. If you want development of virgin country, capital must be encouraged to come. Why is it that to-day the Argentine has £100.000,000 of British "capital invested there? Because the Government of that country realize that to encourage development they must encourage capital, and offer sufficient inducement for the man with the money to invest. If you do the same in the Territory, plenty of capital will be available, for the wool-growing and stock-raising conditions are unsurpassed in any other part of Australia, owing to the formation of the country and its freedom from periodical droughts. This Northern Territory must be looked upon for many years to come as only a sheep and cattleraising proposition.

talk.start.para: - Was Mr. Cotton not speaking of the Barkly Tablelands when he gave that evidence?

- No, he was referring to the Northern Territory generally. We do not say that the Territory is today any more than a sheep and cattleraising proposition. I could quote extensively from the evidence given to the Public Works Committee by men of experience in the pastoral industry who spoke in terms similar to those I have already quoted. Mr. S. J. Mitchell gave this evidence in answer to the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Mathews) -

quote.para: I think that this north-south railway would benefit the Territory as much as many sanguine people think. I am very enthusiastic about it. I am too old to be influenced by sentiment in a matter of this kind. I am looking at the matter in a hard business-like way. The land - is of value, and you cannot settle people there without giving an advantage to the whole of Australia, just as you cannot keep people from those lands without disadvantage to Australia. If it were proposed to carry the central railway further west still, I do not say I would advocate the idea, but it would receive my serious attention. Such a railway would take us into very unsettled country.

speech.para: Sir SidneyKidman, in giving evidence before the same committee, said -

quote.para: There is no comparison between this and the Maree-Birdsville country. At times you can travel from the Macdonnell Ranges on the top feed, but there is nothing the other way. From what I know of the country, there is only one line of any benefit to South Australia, and that is the direct line - that is, the line to open up country which can be stocked with cattle.

speech.para: It is contended by all who advocate the construction of this railway, that it must be constructed in fulfilment of an honorable agreement with the South Australian Government. I did not hear the honorable member for Riverina say anything about the possibilities of mineral development in the Northern Territory. We who advocate the construction of the line contend that there are greater possibilities of mineral development there than in any other part of Australia. The quotations made by the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson) amply demonstrate that. I hope that the Government will not be influenced by anything that has been said against the decision to construct the line, but will finish the. survey as soon as possible, and proceed with the construction work immediately afterwards. I look forward to the first sod of the line being turned within the next twelve months. I said the other day that the construe- tion of roads must be discussed in this House on a future occasion ; the construction of spur lines for the Northern Territory will also have to be discussed. To make the present stock route into a road would entail a large expenditure. Heavy expense would be entailed, apart from the several crossings of the Finke River. At one stage of our trip we travelled only 30 miles from daylight to dark without crossing the Finke River. To make that portion of the track suitable for heavy motor traffic would be enormously expensive. Road transport, moreover, would not provide for the moving of stock from the Northern Territory to South Australia. Every one admits that the -country improves the farther north one goes. It is from the northern part of the line that the cattle will come. The country near Oodnadatta is not good. To be perfectly candid, the existing railway line goes through the worst country in the Territory. The last 120 miles before reaching Oodnadatta is greatly inferior to that just beyond Oodnadatta.
Question resolved in. the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 5 agreed to.
Schedule.

talk.start.para: .- I should like an explanation from the Minister for Defence of several items under the heading of ' ' War and Repatriation Services." Considering the length of time that has elapsed since the end of the war, some of these items appear extraordinary. There is an item of £50,000 for " Expenditure arising out of requisition and use of vessels for transport services in connexion with Expeditionary Forces." It is strange that such an item should appear in a Loan Bill eight years after the end of the war. There are also items, " Refund to Imperial Government of hire money in respect of ex-enemy vessels, £58,000 " ; and " Liabilities in respect of " adjustments between Australian Imperial Force and New Zealand Expeditionary Force abroad, £45,000."

. - The items referred to by the honorable member for Barker (Mr. Cameron") are legacies which I, as Minister for Defence, have inherited. The item of £45,000, which was the principal item to which he referred, was expenditure in connexion with the services of the Australian Imperial Forces. It was originally an item of nearly £75,000. I was instructed by the Government to proceed to New Zealand and interview the Government of that Dominion, and after three days residence there I was able to reach an agreement by which a saving of nearly £30,000 was effected to this Government. The honorable member has pointed out that it is time these items ceased. I think there are only a few of them left, and I hope they will all be cleared up this" financial year.

.- I wish to impress upon the Government the advisability of increasing the wonderful civil aviation service provided in Western Australia and other parts of this country. Between Perth and Derby there is, I think, the best service in Australia. I have always taken a keen interest in the development of the north of Western Australia, and I ask the Government to make a sacrifice to develop that part of the country. Unless we can place people there, we cannot justify our possession of it. Two good things have been done- one is the provision of wireless stations at Camooweal and in the Victoria River country, and the other is the" inauguration of aviation services. The Western Australian service 'has done wonderful work. It has saved several lives, and is of great convenience to the communIty. The aeroplanes have compartments like those of hansom cabs, in which one can read, write, have meals, or go to sleep, without feeling either vibration or hearing noise. I am not seeking any special benefit for Western Australia. I should like the Government to carry the service right round the north-west coast to Darwin, and then link it up with the Queensland service to Longreach. If that were donn, the people in the outback would have a mail service at reasonable intervals, and facilities for transport in case of accident or sickness. On several occasions in Western Australia, patients have been taken to doctors and doctors to patients. The Government ought to do all it can to assist those who have the courage to go into the back country and promote its development. We can always find money for certain things, and it is wonderful with what alacrity the House passes a loan bill for the borrowing of £11,000,000. No question has been asked about how we shall raise the money, or where this policy of borrowing will end. The extent of our borrowing is appalling. There is no financial reason why the Government should not extend the service which I congratulate it upon having inaugurated a few years ago.

quote.para: I wish to refer to the item relating to alterations of lighthouse services. The stores for Cape Borda and Cape de Couedie lighthouses, on Kangaroo Island, are landed by ships' slings, and this operation is carried out with considerable difficulty and danger to human life. Last year, two lives were lost while stores were being landed. It has been strongly urged that the lighthouses should be provisioned by means of a motor service. The present road is impassable, and I ask the Government to make a grant available to enable it to be put in proper order. The road would need to he cleared for about 100 miles, and this work could bc done at small expense.

talk.start.para: .- I endorse the remarks of the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) respecting the urgent need for extending the aerial service from Derby to Wyndham. Under this bill, only £8,500 is provided for civil aviation, but I understand that £250,000 is to be provided for this purpose.
- The Appropriation Bill passed by this House a few days ago made provision for that amount.

- The remote parts of Australia seem to receive scant consideration from the Government. Yet it does not hesitate to encourage some industries by giving them bounties, and to protect others in the congested centres by means of the tariff. The people of the outback country are entitled to more consideration. The honorable member for Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson) has referred to some of the difficulties under which our outback settlers are living. I want to stress the need for the extension of the aerial service from Derby to Wyndham. In the Kimberly district, mails are received once every two months during that portion of the year when the meat works are operating. I wish to give one illustration of the difficulties of the pioneers there. In January last, the wife of a settler was suddenly taken ill on the eve of her departure for Wyndham, a distance of about 160 miles. A message was sent to Wyndham for the doctor. He set out on horseback, but arrived too late, and the unfortunate woman died the following day. If the aeroplane service had been available, two lives would probably have J been saved. Some guarantee of safety should be given to the wives of the men who are prepared to settle in the outback country rather than follow the pleasant vocations of the cities. Honorable members who represent the outback parts of Australia do not obtain the support to which they are justly entitled. I ask the Government to see that our outback settlers receive more consideration.

.- I wish to draw attention to the urgent need for a new post office at Woodside, South Australia. The post office building there is 50 years old, and the dwelling house is over 60 years old. I visited Woodside recently, and inspected those buildings. I found them to be the most disreputable structures there. The town is provided with a continuous telephone service, and is also the centre of an extensive telephone system, being connected with a number of adjacent towns, such as Tweedvale and Balhannah. The accommodation in the post office is inadequate, and the building is dark, damp, and dreary. The post office has an agency for the Commonwealth Bank, but the accommodation is frequently congested, and there is a lack of privacy. The telephonist and the telegraphist work side by side, and their operations are, therefore, considerably cramped. Woodside is deserving of better post office accommodation. The present building is out of date, and it would be quite impossible to renovate it. I urge the Postmaster-General to provide a new post-office there in keeping with the importance of the town.

speech.para: Schedule agreed to.
Title agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill read a third time.
